Title: Fingernails
First Line: Stopped biting my nails when we started sheltering and the next week they scratched my daughter when I held her.
Whole Poem: Stopped biting my nails when we started sheltering and the next week they scratched my daughter when I held her. Seldom had I ever seen nails intact on my troubled fingers, but now I persevered to grow abundant enough to touch any other person. We ate and uttered grace, my own thanks diminished by sincerity. Thank you for not being dead! Seven o’clock. The sunset breathes pink as a gill. We plead applause out open windows desperate to once more belong to we. Pandemic, pan demos, means all people, but our clapping sounds dumb cause it’s not. I wonder if the virus is only envoi, a final sickness following the first: that burst of capital scouring the earth for returns. How gluttonous money flies as half alive as any virus! Superstructural germ, does the wage like you borrow the body’s life until investment finally sunders people extra, mere clippings? The corona seems only the sun’s thin halo, a white keratin rim, and now they say crisis comes when people consume too little, so when my nails grow back I chew them hope hungry, cannibal of my hands, fearing each hangnail a door for the contaminant. Does such solipsism tell you I’ve suffered only paper cuts? It seems that being New Yorkers means we share only one thing. We each hear the red wound wailing in the air, soaking the siren red. The siren burns, the siren spins, but now a different return from that of ambulances and profits. Now spring strikes. Now the workers walk out of warehouses. A judge orders ten migrants unthawed from ice. Is something turning for the people called surplus? Dread of anticipation before no future. Stop biting your nails, says my mother on Skype. She tells me to save the bearded roots of leeks. If you plant them, new shoots regenerate from the trimmings.
Generation -- Title: **Fingernails** by Ken Chen I bite my fingernails to the quick, until they bleed. I am not sure why I do it. It is a habit, a compulsion, a way to relieve stress. When I am feeling anxious or stressed, I bite my fingernails. It is a way to calm myself down, to focus my attention on something else. I know that it is not a good habit, but I can't seem to stop. I am afraid that if I do, I will be overwhelmed by my anxiety. So I continue to bite my fingernails, even though I know it is hurting me. It is a way to cope with my stress, and it is a way to stay sane. I am not sure when I started biting my fingernails. I think it was when I was a child. I remember being in elementary school, and I would always be biting my nails. My teachers would always tell me to stop, but I couldn't help myself. It was like an addiction. I would bite my nails until they were bleeding, and then I would start all over again. I tried to stop biting my nails, but I couldn't do it. I was too addicted. I finally stopped biting my nails when I was in high school. I don't know why I stopped, but I am glad I did. My nails are finally long and healthy, and I am no longer ashamed of them. I am still not sure why I started biting my fingernails, but I am glad that I stopped. It was a bad habit, but I am glad that I am finally free of it.
Generation -- Firstline: Stopped biting my nails when we started sheltering and the next week they scratched my daughter when I held her. I’m not sure if I’m proud of myself or not. I’ve been biting my nails since I was a kid. It’s a nervous habit, I guess. I do it when I’m stressed or anxious. But when the pandemic started, and we all had to stay home, I stopped biting my nails. I don’t know why. Maybe it was because I didn’t have anything else to do. Maybe it was because I was finally able to relax. Whatever the reason, I stopped biting my nails. And for a while, it was great. My nails grew long and strong. I didn’t have to worry about them bleeding or getting infected. But then, one day, I was holding my daughter, and she scratched her face on my nails. I felt terrible. I didn’t mean to hurt her. I tried to be careful after that, but it was hard. My nails were so long, and they kept getting in the way. I started to get frustrated. I started to bite my nails again. It’s not as bad as it used to be, but I still do it sometimes. I’m not sure if I’ll ever be able to stop completely. But I’m trying. For my daughter. And for myself.
Generation -- Firstline Only: I'm so proud of myself for stopping, but I'm also really disappointed that I hurt my daughter. I'm going to keep working on my nails and I'm going to be more careful when I hold her.

Title: Cruel Cogito
First Line: How joyous!, passing this time alone
Whole Poem: How joyous!, passing this time alone with your father, how bright his golden laugh which drew you to laugh yourself uncontrolled, how sweet the happy hour oysters you two pry and eat, piling wobbling shells that glisten on the table while the pianist plays by the kitchen doors. You find yourself reminded of what you wrote in the eulogy: that you two would still possess a relationship even though he was dead, that you could still go and speak with him when you dreamed and so you see the seat opposite from you seats no one.
Generation -- Title: Cruel Cogito by Ken Chen I think, therefore I am. But what if I don't want to be? What if I'm tired of thinking, Of being aware of my own existence? What if I just want to disappear? But I can't. Because I think. And as long as I think, I am. And so I am condemned to this existence, To this constant state of awareness, Of self-consciousness. I am a prisoner of my own mind. I am trapped in my own thoughts. And there is no escape. I am condemned to be.
Generation -- Firstline: How joyous!, passing this time alone How joyous!, passing this time alone, With a cup of wine, I watch the clouds go by. The flowers bloom and fall, the moon waxes and wanes, Yet my heart remains the same. I have no desire for fame or fortune, I only wish to live in peace and contentment. I am content with my humble life, And I am grateful for every day that I am given. I am content with my simple pleasures, A cup of tea, a good book, and the company of my friends. I am content with my life, And I am grateful for every day that I am given.
Generation -- Firstline Only: Joyous is an adjective that means "full of joy". It is often used to describe something that is happy and carefree. In this case, the speaker is using it to describe the time they are spending alone. They are happy and carefree, and they are enjoying their time alone.

Title: Time is Polyphonic
First Line: In those days after his father died, she came to learn that when she could no longer hear what he was doing, when she stopped hearing the turn of a page or typing in the other room that he could only be weeping to himself.
Whole Poem: In those days after his father died, she came to learn that when she could no longer hear what he was doing, when she stopped hearing the turn of a page or typing in the other room that he could only be weeping to himself. Sometimes she would wake in the middle of the night and see the kitchen light on and infer. Many years later, he sees a picture of himself: so young and old and penitent that he feels a strange fondness for this other person. He wonders half-humorously if he had grown wise through grief (he is not wise now) though if anyone had asked, he would have said, ‘I guess I was depressed. I don’t think I learned anything.’ They are in the bedroom. He passes her a glass of bourbon and asks her what he was like then. She says, ‘What, seriously?’ She sees from the whimsical look in his eye that he no longer needed to be defended. She takes a cold sip. ‘You crawled into yourself. I was lonely sometimes. You snapped at me a lot.’
Generation -- Title: Time is polyphonic, A symphony of moments, Each one unique, Yet all connected. The past is a distant echo, The future a faint whisper, But the present is a song, A melody that we can all hear. So let us sing our hearts out, And make the most of every moment, For time is a precious gift, And we should never take it for granted. Time is polyphonic, A symphony of life, And we are all the instruments, Playing our part in the music. So let us play our hearts out, And make the most of this beautiful life, For time is a gift, And we should never waste it.
Generation -- Firstline: In those days after his father died, she came to learn that when she could no longer hear what he was doing, when she stopped hearing the turn of a page or typing in the other room that he could only be weeping to himself. She would sit in the living room, listening for the sound of his breath, the creak of his chair, the clink of his coffee cup. But there was nothing. He had retreated into himself, and she could not reach him. She tried to talk to him, but he would not speak. She tried to touch him, but he would not respond. He was like a ghost, haunting the house, but not really there. She was afraid for him. She did not know what to do. She had never seen him like this before. One day, she came home from work and found him sitting in the living room, staring out the window. He was still and silent, like a statue. She sat down next to him and took his hand. He did not look at her, but she could feel the tears on his cheeks. "I'm here," she said. "I'm not going anywhere." He did not say anything, but she knew he heard her. She stayed with him for a long time, just holding his hand. Eventually, he began to cry more openly. She let him cry, and she cried with him. When he was finally done crying, he looked at her and smiled. "Thank you," he said. "I needed that." She smiled back. "You're welcome," she said. "I'm always here for you." He nodded. "I know," he said. "I know." And for the first time in a long time, she felt like he was really back.

Title: In the Clouds, Volcano
First Line: Earth-touching clouds hush the forest.
Whole Poem: Earth-touching clouds hush the forest. A terrarium of  stillness shrouds the bird realm. Speaking as if  from another source, ‘Apapane the ventriloquist knits its calls, releasing like a ball of string notes that flutter to the floor as leaves, typing trills that glitter the branches. The cloud dome diverts the wind the way a boulder divides a river, rerouting the occasional car from turning down the gravel road. There are many ways to pass through. There are many ways to exit. Solitude expands the sense of  time, on this side of  the hourglass, the sand in short supply. I frittered it away in such a hurry, the arguments, the hostility, grabbing at what I thought would make me happy, so many missed opportunities to make, in the end, amends. I take heed from the old sages. I do not miss the fickleness of  the fleeting world. With my books and papers, I scratch insects out of stone, patch and reclaim torn threads. The stitches are far from perfect. Tobacco-drunk and countless tea cups, I retreat, content beside the twig-fed fire. All that I need is to want nothing more. Rising into clouds, the wisps of  smoke impersonal as my signature.
Generation -- Title: In the Clouds, Volcano Cathy Song In the clouds, volcano smoldering, its cone a perfect circle against the sky. I watch it from my window, the way I used to watch my father when he was sleeping. I would stand in the doorway and stare at him, his face so peaceful, his breath coming and going like the waves on the beach. I would wonder what he was dreaming, and I would wish that I could climb inside his dream and be with him there. Now, as I watch the volcano, I wonder what it is dreaming. Is it dreaming of the day it will erupt, of the lava that will pour from its mouth and destroy everything in its path? Or is it dreaming of peace, of a time when it will be still and quiet and the only sound will be the wind swirling around its cone? I don't know what the volcano is dreaming, but I know that I am dreaming of my father. I am dreaming of the day when I will see him again, and we will be together in a place where there is no pain and no sorrow, only peace.
Generation -- Firstline: Earth-touching clouds hush the forest. A single bird sings. The wind is a hand that strokes my hair. I am a child again, Running through the fields, Chasing butterflies. The sun is a warm smile, The rain is a gentle kiss. I am safe and loved. The world is a place of wonder, Full of beauty and joy. I am grateful for this moment, And for all the moments that have led me here. I am home.

Title: The Blue-Painted Distance
First Line: Torn are the pages from the calendar,
Whole Poem: Torn are the pages from the calendar, the days fluttering past the train’s window, the speed of  which has yet to be perceived for at each seat more immediate are the books about to be opened, the wax-papered sandwiches eaten, the bottles of  strawberry soda consumed. The journey between birth and death are the stations of  joy and sorrow or simple idleness when what remains in relief can be as inconsequential as an unexpected delay that finds you wandering through an afternoon of an old museum. Indistinguishable are the adornments from useful implements, the ill-lit displays of  rocks and shards you circle as if  in a maze, remembering the oddity of  it, startling upon a haunting diorama. Crouched around a glowing fire pit, a family of   hunters and gatherers huddles beneath sheltering skin. All around are the articles of  abundance— meat slabs draped like heavy blankets on a rack, geometric rows of  threads dangling from a loom. The ephemeral made tangible, tongues of cellophane flames cleverly quiver to convey a sense of warmth. Pulled into the scene you follow the trail of smoke across the blue-painted distance of  mesas dotted with bison. Wigs of  black twigs— someone’s idea of  indigenous hair— hide the faces of  the elders. Strapped onto its mother’s back, the lone baby stares unblinkingly at the sky. No one has thought to shut its eyes against the sun, the glare, the rolling cloud waves of  hooves and dust, the flies that will surely come.
Generation -- Title: The Blue-Painted Distance by Cathy Song The blue-painted distance of the horizon is a promise of what is to come. It is a promise of a future that is always out of reach, but always there, just beyond the horizon. The blue-painted distance is a reminder that there is always something more to life, something that we can strive for. So let us set our sights on the blue-painted distance, and let us never give up on the promise of a better future.
Generation -- Firstline: Torn are the pages from the calendar, the months like leaves scattered by the wind. The year is almost over, and I am still here, in this place I no longer recognize. The days are shorter now, the nights longer. The air is cold and damp, and the wind is sharp. The trees are bare, and the ground is hard and dry. The birds have flown south, and the animals have gone into hiding. I am alone here, with my thoughts. I think about the year that has passed, and all the things that have happened. I think about the people I have loved and lost, and the things I have learned. I think about the future, and all the things that might happen. I am not sure what the future holds, but I am not afraid. I am here, now, in this moment. And that is enough.
Generation -- Firstline Only: The days are running out. The clock is ticking, The end is coming. The world is ending, And there's nothing we can do. We can scream and cry and beg for mercy, But it won't make a difference. The end is coming, And there's nothing we can do. So let's just enjoy the ride, And make the most of the time we have left. Let's laugh and love and live, And not worry about the end. Because when it's all said and done, The only thing that matters is that we lived.

Title: April Moon
First Line: The moon tonight is closer to us than it will be for the rest of the year,
Whole Poem: The moon tonight is closer to us than it will be for the rest of the year, grace willing, the year we will remember as the Great Pandemic. Pulling us closer into its orbit, shining the light of its fullness into the room, we turn to hold in our hands each other’s face as if for the first time, and the last— Pink Moon, Egg Moon, Moon of New Grass.
Generation -- Title: April Moon Cathy Song The moon is a white rabbit in the black pool of night. It nibbles on the water lilies, and the water lilies tremble. The moon is a white rabbit in the black pool of night. It drinks the dew from the lotus leaves, and the lotus leaves shiver. The moon is a white rabbit in the black pool of night. It chases the fish, and the fish leap. The moon is a white rabbit in the black pool of night. It plays hide-and-seek with the stars, and the stars wink.

I want to reach up and touch it, feel its cool skin against my fingertips. I want to take a bite, taste its sweetness. But I know that if I do, it will disappear. So I stand here, admiring it from afar, and savoring the moment. The moon is a reminder that even though things may seem close, they can also be fleeting. So we should cherish the moments we have, and make the most of them. For the moon tonight, as close as it may seem, will soon be gone.
Generation -- Firstline Only: The moon tonight is at perigee, which means it is at its closest point to Earth in its orbit. This makes it appear about 14% larger and 30% brighter than when it is at apogee, which is its farthest point from Earth.

Title: The Kindness of Others
First Line: The kindness of others is all they ever wanted, the laughter of neighbors prospering in the blue light of summer.
Whole Poem: The kindness of others is all they ever wanted, the laughter of neighbors prospering in the blue light of summer. Those of the small sputtering flame and the sudden white sprung hair, who feed off envy and grow old quickly, desire largesse. The role of poor relation evokes a lack they are not apt to admit, or unbearable pity. They prefer to penetrate the giver’s effortless knack of giving they perceive as vitality, a pulsating entity that rewards the kindness of others tenfold. This they have witnessed. This they have tabulated relentlessly. The generosity of others whose spirits, like their long-legged children blossoming into a progeny of orchards and fields, flourish. Those who have never known kindness drag into the privacy of their smallness the baskets of fruit appearing year after year on their porches, to be picked apart in the hushed posture of thieves. They peel skin, probe flesh the color of honey as if the seeds will yield something other than a glimmer of sweet air rising from the roots of trees and licorice-laced, half-opened leaves. Those of the small flame, who feed off envy and grow old quickly, live out their lives hungry, glaring at themselves across the table, wife of the cruel mouth, husband of the thin broth trickling like spittle.
Generation -- Title: The Kindness of Others by Cathy Song I am grateful for the kindness of others, the unexpected gift, the unexpected smile, the unexpected helping hand. I am grateful for the kindness of strangers, who offer me directions when I am lost, who hold the door open for me, who smile at me on the street. I am grateful for the kindness of friends, who are always there for me, who listen to me when I need to talk, who laugh with me when I am happy. I am grateful for the kindness of family, who love me unconditionally, who support me in everything I do, who are always there for me. I am grateful for the kindness of others, who make the world a more beautiful place. They are the ones who make me believe that there is still good in the world, that there is still hope. They are the ones who make me feel loved, who make me feel like I belong. They are the ones who make me a better person. I am grateful for the kindness of others.
Generation -- Firstline: The kindness of others is all they ever wanted, the laughter of neighbors prospering in the blue light of summer. They wanted to be known for their generosity, for the way they always put others before themselves. They wanted to be remembered for their kindness, for the way they made everyone feel welcome and loved. They were the kind of people who would give you the shirt off their back, even if they didn't have another one to wear. They were the kind of people who would help you move, even if they were in the middle of their own move. They were the kind of people who would always be there for you, no matter what. They were the kind of people who made the world a better place. And now they're gone. But their kindness lives on. Their laughter echoes through the streets. Their memory is a blessing to all who knew them. They were truly special people, and they will never be forgotten.

Title: [Yesterday, the sunshine made the air glow]
First Line: Yesterday, the sunshine made the air glow pushing me like a sixteen-year-old
Whole Poem: Yesterday, the sunshine made the air glow pushing me like a sixteen-year-old to toss my shirt off, and run along the river shore, splashing in the water, wading out to the reeds, my heart an ancient Yaki drum and I believed, more than believed, the air beneath trees was female blue dancers I approached, and there in the dry leaves, in the crisp twigs, I turned softly as if dancing with a blue woman made of air, sunlight, in shrub-weed skirts. I knew the dance that would please the Gods, I knew the dance that would make the river water smile glistening ever silvering, I knew the dance steps that praised my ancestors. Yeah, I wanted to write you a poem woman for two days, and today it was gray and snowy and overcast, about how I startled the mallards from their shallow refuge beneath the Russian olive trees and how the male purposely came close to me diverting my attention to it its female love went the other way risking its life, that's what I saw, the male fly before the hunter's rifles, circle in sights of hunters and take the shots, the roaring rifle blast after blast and circle beyond over the fields to meet its female companion. That's how I miss you, that's how I wanted to write you a poem since we left you one way me another way. I was the male taking with me the hunters that would harm you risking my heart so yours wouldn't be hurt, fronting myself as possible prey so you could escape, that kind of poem I am writing you now. Circling as hunters aim down on me while you rise, rise, rise into the blue sky and meet me over in the next fields. I wanted to write you a poem for two days now to tell you how happy I was, seeing a white crane arc between banks in the irrigation ditch with furious efforts, its big wings flapping like an awkward nine-year-old kid much taller than the others his age with size twelve sneakers flapping down the basketball court. But once the white crane found its balance, its wings their grace, it glided more perfectly than a ballet dancer's leap across air, all of its feathers ballet dancer's toes, all of its feathers delicate dancers all of its feathers, in motion made me believe in myself, but more, when it rose, swooped up, the line of ascent up made me think of the curve of your spine, how I traced my finger down your spine when you slept, your spine is the ascent of the crane toward the sunshine, and my hands my face my torso and chest and legs and hips became air, a blue cold artic air you glided up in your song of winter love.
Generation -- Title: [Yesterday, the sunshine made the air glow] Yesterday, the sunshine made the air glow, and I felt like a child again, running through the fields, laughing and shouting. The sun was warm on my skin, and the wind was in my hair, and I felt free. I ran and ran, until I couldn't run anymore, and then I lay down in the grass, and looked up at the sky. The clouds were like cotton candy, and the birds were singing, and I felt happy. I closed my eyes and listened to the sounds of the world, and I felt at peace. I knew that everything was going to be okay. Today, the sun is still shining, but I don't feel like a child anymore. I'm older now, and I have responsibilities, and I can't just run through the fields, laughing and shouting. But I can still remember how it felt, to be young and free, and I can still find joy in the simple things, like the sunshine, and the wind, and the birds singing. And I know that everything is going to be okay.
Generation -- Firstline: Yesterday, the sunshine made the air glow pushing me like a sixteen-year-old down the street, past the corner store, where the old men sat on benches, talking about the weather, and the young men played basketball, and the girls walked by, their hair blowing in the wind. I walked past them all, feeling the sun on my back, and the wind in my hair, and the world at my feet. I was sixteen again, and the world was mine.
Generation -- Firstline Only: Yesterday, the sunshine made the air glow, Pushing me like a sixteen-year-old. I ran through the park, laughing and shouting, Feeling the wind in my hair and the sun on my face. I was filled with joy and exuberance, And I felt like I could do anything. I thought about all the things I wanted to do with my life, And I knew that I could achieve anything I set my mind to. I was filled with hope and possibility, And I couldn't wait to see what the future held. Yesterday, the sunshine made the air glow, And it pushed me to be the best version of myself. I am grateful for that day, And I will never forget the feeling of being sixteen again.

Title: I Am Offering this Poem
First Line: I am offering this poem to you, since I have nothing else to give.
Whole Poem: I am offering this poem to you, since I have nothing else to give. Keep it like a warm coat when winter comes to cover you, or like a pair of thick socks the cold cannot bite through, I love you, I have nothing else to give you, so it is a pot full of yellow corn to warm your belly in winter, it is a scarf for your head, to wear over your hair, to tie up around your face, I love you, Keep it, treasure this as you would if you were lost, needing direction, in the wilderness life becomes when mature; and in the corner of your drawer, tucked away like a cabin or hogan in dense trees, come knocking, and I will answer, give you directions, and let you warm yourself by this fire, rest by this fire, and make you feel safe I love you, It’s all I have to give, and all anyone needs to live, and to go on living inside, when the world outside no longer cares if you live or die; remember, I love you.
Generation -- Title: I Am Offering this Poem I am offering this poem to you, my friend, a gift from my heart to yours. I offer it with love and hope that it will bring you joy and peace. I offer it with the knowledge that we are all connected, that we are all one, and that we are all in this together. I offer it with the hope that we will all find our way home, to each other, to ourselves, and to the Divine. So please accept this poem with open arms, and let it fill your heart with love and light. Thank you for being my friend.
Generation -- Firstline: I am offering this poem to you, Since I have nothing else to give. It is a gift from my heart, A small token of my love. I hope you will accept it with grace, And cherish it always. For it is my way of saying, "I care about you." I know that words are not enough, But they are all I have to offer. So please accept this poem, And know that it comes from the depths of my soul. I hope that one day, I will be able to give you more than words. But for now, This is all I have to offer. So please accept it with love, And know that I will always be here for you.

I hope these words will touch your soul, And bring you a measure of joy. May they remind you that you are not alone, And that someone cares. Thank you for taking the time to read my poem. It was my pleasure to share it with you.

Title: Sanctuary
First Line: for Tony I could not disengage my world from the rest of humanity.
Whole Poem: for Tony I could not disengage my world from the rest of humanity. Wind chill factor 11° below. All night wind thrashes barechested trees like a West Texas tent evangelist hissing them on his knees, lisping sinnn . . . sinn . . . sinn . . . All night wind preaches. Old tool shed behind my house fist-cuffs itself to nail-loose tin, horse pasture gates clank their crimes, while neighing black stallions of rain stampede on the patio fleeing gunshots of thunder . . . . Miles south of here, nightscopes pick up human heat that green fuzz helicopter dash panels. A mother whispers, “Sssshhhh mejito, nomás poco más allá. Nomás poco más allá.” Dunes of playing-dead people jack rabbit under strobe lights and cutting whack/blades, “Ssshhh mejito. Sssshhhh.” Child whimpers and staggers in blinding dust and gnashing wind. Those not caught, scratch sand up to sleep against underbellies of roots and stones. Eventually Juanito comes to my door, sick from eating stucco chips— his meals scratched off walls of temporary shelters, and Enrique, who guzzled water at industrial pipes pouring green foam out at the El Paso/Juarez border, and Maria steaming with fever, face dark meteorite, whispers, “Where I come from, Señor Baca, a woman’s womb is a rock, and children born from me, drop like stones, to become dust under death squad’s boots.” And Juanito, “They came at midnight and took my brothers. I have never seen them since. Each judge’s tongue is a bleeding stub of death, and each lawyer’s finger a soft coffin nail.” And Enrique, “You can trust no one. Each crying person’s eye is a damp cellar where thieves and murderers sleep.” They have found refuge here at Black Mesa. The sun passes between our lives, as between two trees, one gray, one green, but side by side.
Generation -- Title: Sanctuary Jimmy Santiago Baca I am a man of the earth, I am a man of the sky, I am a man of the sea, I am a man of the stars. I am a man of the mountains, I am a man of the valleys, I am a man of the forests, I am a man of the deserts. I am a man of the past, I am a man of the present, I am a man of the future, I am a man of all time. I am a man of many colors, I am a man of many languages, I am a man of many cultures, I am a man of the world. I am a man of peace, I am a man of love, I am a man of hope, I am a man of dreams. I am a man of the universe, I am a man of God, I am a man of all creation, I am a man of everything. I am a man, And I am proud.

I want you to know that I'm here for you, and I'll support you in any way I can. I know that you're a strong person, and I believe that you'll fight this with everything you've got. I'm also confident that you'll find a way to live a full and happy life, even with this diagnosis. I've been thinking about what I can do to help you. I know that you're not the kind of person who wants to be pitied, so I won't offer that. But I can offer my friendship, my support, and my love. I'm here to listen to you, to help you with anything you need, and to just be there for you. I also want to remind you that you're not alone. There are many people who care about you, and we're all here for you. We'll support you through this, and we'll help you to live a full and happy life. I love you, Tony. Sincerely, [Your name]

Title: Immigrants in Our Own Land
First Line: We are born with dreams in our hearts, looking for better days ahead.
Whole Poem: We are born with dreams in our hearts, looking for better days ahead. At the gates we are given new papers, our old clothes are taken and we are given overalls like mechanics wear. We are given shots and doctors ask questions. Then we gather in another room where counselors orient us to the new land we will now live in. We take tests. Some of us were craftsmen in the old world, good with our hands and proud of our work. Others were good with their heads. They used common sense like scholars use glasses and books to reach the world. But most of us didn’t finish high school. The old men who have lived here stare at us, from deep disturbed eyes, sulking, retreated. We pass them as they stand around idle, leaning on shovels and rakes or against walls. Our expectations are high: in the old world, they talked about rehabilitation, about being able to finish school, and learning an extra good trade. But right away we are sent to work as dishwashers, to work in fields for three cents an hour. The administration says this is temporary So we go about our business, blacks with blacks, poor whites with poor whites, chicanos and indians by themselves. The administration says this is right, no mixing of cultures, let them stay apart, like in the old neighborhoods we came from. We came here to get away from false promises, from dictators in our neighborhoods, who wore blue suits and broke our doors down when they wanted, arrested us when they felt like, swinging clubs and shooting guns as they pleased. But it’s no different here. It’s all concentrated. The doctors don’t care, our bodies decay, our minds deteriorate, we learn nothing of value. Our lives don’t get better, we go down quick. My cell is crisscrossed with laundry lines, my T-shirts, boxer shorts, socks and pants are drying. Just like it used to be in my neighborhood: from all the tenements laundry hung window to window. Across the way Joey is sticking his hands through the bars to hand Felipé a cigarette, men are hollering back and forth cell to cell, saying their sinks don’t work, or somebody downstairs hollers angrily about a toilet overflowing, or that the heaters don’t work. I ask Coyote next door to shoot me over a little more soap to finish my laundry. I look down and see new immigrants coming in, mattresses rolled up and on their shoulders, new haircuts and brogan boots, looking around, each with a dream in their heart, thinking they’ll get a chance to change their lives. But in the end, some will just sit around talking about how good the old world was. Some of the younger ones will become gangsters. Some will die and others will go on living without a soul, a future, or a reason to live. Some will make it out of here with hate in their eyes, but so very few make it out of here as human as they came in, they leave wondering what good they are now as they look at their hands so long away from their tools, as they look at themselves, so long gone from their families, so long gone from life itself, so many things have changed.
Generation -- Firstline: We are born with dreams in our hearts, Looking for better days ahead. We dream of a world where there is peace, Where everyone is treated with respect, And where everyone has enough to eat. We dream of a world where the environment is protected, Where the air is clean and the water is clear, And where the forests are full of life. We dream of a world where everyone has access to education, Where everyone is free to express themselves, And where everyone can live in a safe and healthy community. We dream of a world where everyone is happy, Where everyone is loved, And where everyone feels like they belong. We are born with dreams in our hearts, And we will never stop dreaming until we make those dreams a reality.
Generation -- Firstline Only: We are born with the potential to achieve great things, to make a difference in the world. But sometimes, life gets in the way. We get discouraged, we give up on our dreams. We forget that we are capable of anything we set our minds to. But I'm here to remind you that you are not alone. We all have dreams, and we all have the potential to achieve them. We just need to remember that we are capable, and we need to never give up. So if you're feeling discouraged, remember this: you are not alone. You are capable of anything you set your mind to. Never give up on your dreams.

Title: Loose Woman
First Line: They say I’m a beast. And feast on it.
Whole Poem: They say I’m a beast. And feast on it. When all along I thought that’s what a woman was. They say I’m a bitch. Or witch. I’ve claimed the same and never winced. They say I’m a macha, hell on wheels, viva-la-vulva, fire and brimstone, man-hating, devastating, boogey-woman lesbian. Not necessarily, but I like the compliment. The mob arrives with stones and sticks to maim and lame and do me in. All the same, when I open my mouth, they wobble like gin. Diamonds and pearls tumble from my tongue. Or toads and serpents. Depending on the mood I’m in. I like the itch I provoke. The rustle of rumor like crinoline. I am the woman of myth and bullshit. (True. I authored some of it.) I built my little house of ill repute. Brick by brick. Labored, loved and masoned it. I live like so. Heart as sail, ballast, rudder, bow. Rowdy. Indulgent to excess. My sin and success– I think of me to gluttony. By all accounts I am a danger to society. I’m Pancha Villa. I break laws, upset the natural order, anguish the Pope and make fathers cry. I am beyond the jaw of law. I’m la desperada, most-wanted public enemy. My happy picture grinning from the wall. I strike terror among the men. I can’t be bothered what they think. ¡Que se vayan a la ching chang chong! For this, the cross, the calvary. In other words, I’m anarchy. I’m an aim-well, shoot-sharp, sharp-tongued, sharp-thinking, fast-speaking, foot-loose, loose-tongued, let-loose, woman-on-the-loose loose woman. Beware, honey. I’m Bitch. Beast. Macha. ¡Wáchale! Ping! Ping! Ping! I break things.
Generation -- Firstline: They say I’m a beast. And feast on it. They say I’m a savage. And tame me. They say I’m a wild thing. And they cage me. They say I’m a mystery. And they lock me away. But I am a woman. I am a woman with a soft tongue. I am a woman with a gentle heart. I am a woman with a strong back. I am a woman with a fierce soul. I am a woman. And I will not be tamed. I will not be caged. I will not be locked away. I am a woman. And I will rise.

Title: Abuelita Who
First Line: Abuelito who throws coins like rain
Whole Poem: Abuelito who throws coins like rain and asks who loves him who is dough and feathers who is a watch and glass of water whose hair is made of fur is too sad to come downstairs today who tells me in Spanish you are my diamond who tells me in English you are my sky whose little eyes are string can’t come out to play sleeps in his little room all night and day who used to laugh like the letter k is sick is a doorknob tied to a sour stick is tired shut the door doesn’t live here anymore is hiding underneath the bed who talks to me inside my head is blankets and spoons and big brown shoes who snores up and down up and down up and down again is the rain on the roof that falls like coins asking who loves him who loves him who?
Generation -- Title: Abuelita Who by Sandra Cisneros Abuelita who tells me stories of the time when she was young and the world was a different place, when she would go to the market and buy a kilo of tomatoes and a dozen eggs and a piece of meat and a loaf of bread and a jar of milk and a sack of beans and a bag of rice and a bottle of Coke and still have change from a dollar. Abuelita who sews my clothes and mends my socks and tells me stories of the time when she was young and the world was a different place, when she would go to the park and watch the children play and the flowers bloom and the birds sing and the sun shine and she would feel happy. Abuelita who cooks the best food in the world and makes me feel loved and tells me stories of the time when she was young and the world was a different place, when she would dance the night away and sing her heart out and laugh until her sides hurt and she would feel happy. Abuelita who is always there for me no matter what and tells me stories of the time when she was young and the world was a different place, when she was full of hope and dreams and possibilities and she would feel happy.
Generation -- Firstline: Abuelito Who Throws Coins Like Rain by Sandra Cisneros Abuelito who throws coins like rain into the fountain, the pigeons scatter, their wings clapping like applause. He laughs, his teeth like a row of white dominoes. He holds my hand and we dance in the spray, the water cool on our faces. I close my eyes and feel the sun on my skin, the wind in my hair, and the love of my Abuelo all around me.
Generation -- Firstline Only: Abuelito throws coins like rain, A shower of silver and gold. He scatters them on the ground, And the children run to catch them. They laugh and shout with glee, As they fill their pockets with treasure. Abuelito smiles as he watches them, And his heart is filled with joy. He knows that he is giving them a gift, A gift that will last a lifetime. The gift of happiness. So Abuelito continues to throw coins, And the children continue to catch them. And in the midst of the rain, There is a rainbow of joy.

Title: Dulzura
First Line: Make love to me in Spanish.
Whole Poem: Make love to me in Spanish. Not with that other tongue. I want you juntito a mi, tender like the language crooned to babies. I want to be that lullabied, mi bien querido, that loved. I want you inside the mouth of my heart, inside the harp of my wrists, the sweet meat of the mango, in the gold that dangles from my ears and neck. Say my name. Say it. The way it’s supposed to be said. I want to know that I knew you even before I knew you.
Generation -- Firstline Only: Hazme el amor.

Title: My Name
First Line: In English my name means hope. In Spanish it means too many letters.
Whole Poem: In English my name means hope. In Spanish it means too many letters. It means sadness, it means waiting. It is like the number nine. A muddy color. It is the Mexican records my father plays on Sunday mornings when he is shaving, songs like sobbing. It was my great-grandmother's name and now it is mine. She was a horse woman too, born like me in the Chinese year of the horse--which is supposed to be bad luck if you're born female-but I think this is a Chinese lie because the Chinese, like the Mexicans, don't like their women strong. My great-grandmother. I would've liked to have known her, a wild, horse of a woman, so wild she wouldn't marry. Until my great-grandfather threw a sack over her head and carried her off. Just like that, as if she were a fancy chandelier. That's the way he did it. And the story goes she never forgave him. She looked out the window her whole life, the way so many women sit their sadness on an elbow. I wonder if she made the best with what she got or was she sorry because she couldn't be all the things she wanted to be. Esperanza. I have inherited her name, but I don't want to inherit her place by the window. At school they say my name funny as if the syllables were made out of tin and hurt the roof of your mouth. But in Spanish my name is made out of a softer something, like silver, not quite as thick as sister's name Magdalena--which is uglier than mine. Magdalena who at least- -can come home and become Nenny. But I am always Esperanza. would like to baptize myself under a new name, a name more like the real me, the one nobody sees. Esperanza as Lisandra or Maritza or Zeze the X. Yes. Something like Zeze the X will do.
Generation -- Title: My Name by Sandra Cisneros My name is so long it takes two buses to say it. The first bus drops me off at the M's, the second bus at the As. I run between them, my name scattering in the street. M-A-R-I-E-L-A. I am a train with many cars. I am a long song sung by a choir. I am a river with many tributaries. I am a forest with many trees. I am a house with many rooms. I am a family with many members. My name is so long it takes a long time to say it. But in Spanish it is only five letters. María. Just five letters. And yet, it is so much more.
Generation -- Firstline Only: Esperanza

Title: The Contract Says: We'd Like the Conversation to be Bilingual
First Line: When you come, bring your brown- ness so we can be sure to please
Whole Poem: When you come, bring your brown- ness so we can be sure to please the funders. Will you check this box; we’re applying for a grant. Do you have any poems that speak to troubled teens? Bilingual is best. Would you like to come to dinner with the patrons and sip Patrón? Will you tell us the stories that make us uncomfortable, but not complicit? Don’t read the one where you are just like us. Born to a green house, garden, don’t tell us how you picked tomatoes and ate them in the dirt watching vultures pick apart another bird’s bones in the road. Tell us the one about your father stealing hubcaps after a colleague said that’s what his kind did. Tell us how he came to the meeting wearing a poncho and tried to sell the man his hubcaps back. Don’t mention your father was a teacher, spoke English, loved making beer, loved baseball, tell us again about the poncho, the hubcaps, how he stole them, how he did the thing he was trying to prove he didn’t do.
Generation -- Title: The Contract Says: We'd Like the Conversation to be Bilingual by Ada Limón The contract says: We'd like the conversation to be bilingual. I say, "Yes, I can do that." I've been speaking two languages since I was a child. I can switch back and forth, from English to Spanish, like a light switch. I can speak English to my boss, and Spanish to my mother. I can speak English to my students, and Spanish to my friends. I can speak English to the world, and Spanish to my soul. But sometimes, when I'm speaking two languages at once, I feel like I'm losing something. I feel like I'm not fully expressing myself. I feel like I'm not being understood. So I stop speaking two languages at once. I choose one language. I speak English. I speak Spanish. But I never forget the other language. I never forget that I'm bilingual. I never forget that I'm a bridge between two worlds.
Generation -- Firstline: When you come, bring your brown- ness so we can be sure to please. We’ll set out the good china, the embroidered tablecloth, the silver candlesticks. We’ll put on the music you like, the music that makes you dance. We’ll cook your favorite foods, the ones that remind you of home. We’ll make you feel welcome, so welcome that you’ll never want to leave. But when you leave, take your brown- ness with you. Don’t leave it here, where it will be swallowed up by the whiteness. Take it back to your home, where it belongs. Let it remind you of the people who love you, the people who made you feel welcome. Let it remind you that you are not alone.

Title: A New National Anthem
First Line: The truth is, I’ve never cared for the National Anthem.
Whole Poem: The truth is, I’ve never cared for the National Anthem. If you think about it, it’s not a good song. Too high for most of us with “the rockets red glare” and then there are the bombs. (Always, always, there is war and bombs.) Once, I sang it at homecoming and threw even the tenacious high school band off key. But the song didn’t mean anything, just a call to the field, something to get through before the pummeling of youth. And what of the stanzas we never sing, the third that mentions “no refuge could save the hireling and the slave”? Perhaps, the truth is, every song of this country has an unsung third stanza, something brutal snaking underneath us as we blindly sing the high notes with a beer sloshing in the stands hoping our team wins. Don’t get me wrong, I do like the flag, how it undulates in the wind like water, elemental, and best when it’s humbled, brought to its knees, clung to by someone who has lost everything, when it’s not a weapon, when it flickers, when it folds up so perfectly you can keep it until it’s needed, until you can love it again, until the song in your mouth feels like sustenance, a song where the notes are sung by even the ageless woods, the short-grass plains, the Red River Gorge, the fistful of land left unpoisoned, that song that’s our birthright, that’s sung in silence when it’s too hard to go on, that sounds like someone’s rough fingers weaving into another’s, that sounds like a match being lit in an endless cave, the song that says my bones are your bones, and your bones are my bones, and isn’t that enough?
Generation -- Title: **A New National Anthem** When I say the word America, I don't mean bald eagles or apple pie or baseball. I mean the sound of waves crashing against the shore, the smell of jasmine in the air, the taste of fresh-picked strawberries. I mean the stories of immigrants who came here with nothing and built a better life for themselves. I mean the resilience of the people who have endured slavery, war, and economic hardship. I mean the beauty of our national parks, the diversity of our cultures, the strength of our democracy. I mean the promise of America, a place where everyone is welcome, where everyone can achieve their dreams, where everyone can be free. This is the America I love. This is the America I sing about.
Generation -- Firstline: The truth is, I’ve never cared for the National Anthem. It’s too long, for one thing. And the melody is so somber, like a dirge. I’d rather sing “Happy Birthday” or “The Star-Spangled Banner.” But I do love the part about the rockets’ red glare, the bombs bursting in air. It’s so dramatic! And the line “O say can you see by the dawn’s early light” is so beautiful. I also love the fact that the National Anthem is a poem. It’s a reminder that poetry is important, that it can be used to express patriotism and pride. So even though I don’t always sing along, I still appreciate the National Anthem. It’s a part of our history, and it’s a reminder of all that we have to be grateful for.
Generation -- Firstline Only: The truth is, I’ve never cared for the National Anthem. I’ve never been moved by the soaring melody or the stirring lyrics. To me, it’s just a song—a patriotic song, sure, but no more or less meaningful than any other song. I know that many people love the National Anthem. They see it as a symbol of our country and our shared values. I respect that, but I just don’t feel the same way. To me, the National Anthem is just a song—and not even a very good one. I’m not saying that I don’t love my country. I do. I’m just saying that I don’t need a song to express that love. I can do that just fine on my own. I know that some people will think I’m unpatriotic for saying this. But I don’t care. I’m not going to pretend to love a song just because it’s the National Anthem. I’m going to be honest about how I feel, even if it means offending some people. I know that I’m not the only one who feels this way. There are other people out there who don’t care for the National Anthem either. We’re not unpatriotic. We just don’t see the National Anthem as the sacred symbol that some people do. So, if you’re one of those people who doesn’t care for the National Anthem, don’t feel like you have to pretend to love it. Just be honest about how you feel. It’s okay.

Title: The Raincoat
First Line: When the doctor suggested surgery and a brace for all my youngest years,
Whole Poem: When the doctor suggested surgery and a brace for all my youngest years, my parents scrambled to take me to massage therapy, deep tissue work, osteopathy, and soon my crooked spin unspooled a bit, I could breathe again, and move more in a body unclouded by pain. My mom would tell me to sing songs to her the whole forty-five-minute drive to Middle Two Rock Road and forty- five minutes back from physical therapy. She’d say that even my voice sounded unfettered by my spine afterward. So I sang and sang, because I thought she liked it. I never asked her what she gave up to drive me, or how her day was before this chore. Today, at her age, I was driving myself home from yet another spine appointment, singing along to some maudlin but solid song on the radio, and I saw a mom take her raincoat off and give it to her young daughter when a storm took over the afternoon. My god, I thought, my whole life I’ve been under her raincoat thinking it was somehow a marvel that I never got wet.
Generation -- Title: The Raincoat by Ada Limón I wear this raincoat like a second skin, like a river I can hide in. I wear it when I'm sad, when I'm scared, when I don't want to be seen. I wear it when I'm walking in the rain, and the rain is falling so hard I can't see where I'm going. I wear it when I'm standing in the middle of a crowd, and I feel like I'm all alone. I wear it when I'm talking to someone, and I don't want them to see what's really inside me. But sometimes, I take off my raincoat, and I let the rain fall on me. And I feel the water wash away all the sadness and the fear, and I feel like I can breathe again. And I feel like I can be seen.
Generation -- Firstline: When the doctor suggested surgery and a brace for all my youngest years, I thought of the stories my mother told me of her own childhood, of the surgeries and the braces, of the way she’d been told she’d never walk again. But she did walk again, and she ran, and she danced, and she raised a family, and she lived a full and beautiful life. So I took the doctor’s advice, and I had the surgery, and I wore the brace, and I went through the pain, and I healed. And I learned that even when the world tells you that you can’t, you can. You can walk, you can run, you can dance, you can live a full and beautiful life. You are stronger than you think. You are more resilient than you know. You are capable of anything you set your mind to. So don’t let anyone tell you otherwise. You are enough.

Title: Dream of the Raven
First Line: When the ten-speed, lightweight bicycle broke down
Whole Poem: When the ten-speed, lightweight bicycle broke down off the highway linded thick with orange trees, I noticed a giant raven’s head protruding from the waxy leaves. The bird was stuck somehow, mangled in the branches, crying out. Wide-eyed, I held the bird’s face close to mine. Beak to nose. Dark brown iris to dark brown iris. Feather to feather. This was not the Chihuahuan raven or the fantailed raven or the common raven. Nothing was common about the way we stared at one another while a stranger untangled the bird’s claws from the tree’s limbs and he, finally free, became a naked child swinging in the wind.
Generation -- Title: Dream of the Raven by Ada Limón I dream of the raven who lives in the tree outside my window. He is black as night, with a long, sharp beak and piercing eyes. He sits on a branch, watching me with his unblinking gaze. I wonder what he sees when he looks at me. Does he see the fear I feel when I look into his eyes? Or does he see the curiosity that I feel when I watch him fly? I am drawn to him, even though I know he is a wild creature. There is something about him that is both mysterious and alluring. I dream that I am flying with him, over the treetops, the wind in our hair. We soar through the sky, free from all that weighs us down. When I wake up, I feel a sense of loss. I know that I will never be able to fly with the raven again, but I will never forget the feeling of freedom that I felt when I was with him.
Generation -- Firstline: When the ten-speed, lightweight bicycle broke down I left it on the side of the road and walked the rest of the way home. The sun was setting, and the sky was a riot of color. I watched it as I walked, and I thought about all the things that had broken down in my life. My first marriage, my first car, my first heart. I thought about all the times I had been left by the side of the road, and how I had always found a way to keep walking. I thought about all the times I had been broken down, and how I had always found a way to put myself back together. And I realized that even though the bicycle was broken, it didn't mean that I was. I was still here, I was still walking, and I was still alive. And that was enough.
Generation -- Firstline Only: The ten-speed, lightweight bicycle broke down.

Title: National Park
First Line: We saw a lot more of them dead than alive
Whole Poem: We saw a lot more of them dead than alive the living diffident by the side of the road as the far-off mountains flanked and intoxicated the speedometer into saunter The dead were interspersed on the asphalt their poor vision uncorrected by their auditory keenness like a blind spot in a poet and their fender-mangled corpses were occasionally ripped in two before vultures reached them In our rental van we left no mother bereft and orphaned no piglets Turkey buzzards and American vultures were the javelinas’ gift to us red and black scavengers that perched on ranchland fences the full span of highway they’d circle above in diminishing downward spirals or flinch at each other’s puffs and swells or away from incoming vehicles Still they shared the dead among them as we sometimes share our dead when we love our dead Javelina the Arabic word for mountain in its root and then the mountain coming closer to an ear became a spear

It is a place to find peace and quiet, to commune with nature, to be one with the trees. The park is a place of beauty, a place to see the wonders of creation, the towering mountains, the sparkling lakes, the lush forests. The park is a place of wonder, a place to learn about the natural world, about the animals that live there, the plants that grow there. The park is a place of adventure, a place to explore, to hike, to camp, to fish. The park is a place of memories, a place to make new memories, to share with family and friends. The park is a place of love, a place to find love, to lose love, to remember love. The park is a place of life, a place to live, to laugh, to cry. The park is a place of hope, a place to find hope, to dream, to believe. The park is a place of peace, a place to find peace, to be at peace, to be home.
Generation -- Firstline: We saw a lot more of them dead than alive We saw a lot more of them dead than alive, and when we saw them alive, they were always running. We saw them running from the bombs, from the bullets, from the tanks, from the soldiers, from the militias, from the death squads, from the executioners. We saw them running through the streets, through the fields, through the forests, through the mountains, through the deserts. We saw them running for their lives. We saw them running and we did not know what to do. We wanted to help them, but we did not know how. We were afraid. We were afraid of the bombs, of the bullets, of the tanks, of the soldiers, of the militias, of the death squads, of the executioners. We were afraid of being killed. So we did nothing. We watched them run and we did nothing. We watched them die and we did nothing. And now we are ashamed. We are ashamed of what we did not do. We are ashamed of our silence. We are ashamed of our fear. We are ashamed of ourselves. But we will not be silent anymore. We will not be afraid anymore. We will not let them kill us. We will fight back. We will fight for our lives. We will fight for our freedom. We will fight for our dignity. We will fight for our future. And we will win.

Title: Mimesis
First Line: My daughter wouldn’t hurt a spider That had nested
Whole Poem: My daughter wouldn’t hurt a spider That had nested Between her bicycle handles For two weeks She waited Until it left of its own accord If you tear down the web I said It will simply know This isn’t a place to call home And you’d get to go biking She said that’s how others Become refugees isn’t it?

Title: Progress Notes
First Line: The age of portrait is drugged. Beauty is symmetry so rare it’s a mystery.
Whole Poem: The age of portrait is drugged. Beauty is symmetry so rare it’s a mystery. My left eye is smaller than my right, my big mouth shows my nice teeth perfectly aligned like Muslims in prayer. My lips an accordion. Each sneeze a facial thumbprint. One corner of my mouth hangs downward when I want to hold a guffaw hostage. Bell’s palsy perhaps or what Mark Twain said about steamboat piloting, that a doctor’s unable to look upon the blush in a young beauty’s face without thinking it could be a fever, a malar rash, a butterfly announcing a wolf. Can I lie facedown now as cadavers posed on first anatomy lesson? I didn’t know mine was a woman until three weeks later we turned her over. Out of reverence there was to be no untimely exposure of donors, our patrons who were covered in patches of scrubs-green dish towels, and by semester’s end we were sick of all that, tossed mega livers and mammoth hearts into lab air and caught them. My body was Margaret. That’s what the death certificate said when it was released before finals. The cause of her death? Nothing memorable, frail old age. But the colonel on table nineteen with an accessory spleen had put a bullet through his temple, a final prayer. Not in entry or exit were there skull cracks to condemn the house of death, no shattered glass in the brain, only a smooth tunnel of deep violet that bloomed in concentric circles. The weekends were lonely. He had the most beautiful muscles of all 32 bodies that were neatly arranged, zipped up as if a mass grave had been disinterred. Or when unzipped and facing the ceiling had cloth over their eyes as if they’d just been executed. Gray silver hair, chiseled countenance, he was sixty-seven, a veteran of more than one war. I had come across that which will end me, ex­- tend me, at least once, without knowing it.
Generation -- Title: **Progress Notes** The doctor says, "You're doing well, Your blood pressure is down, Your pulse is strong, Your lungs are clear." I say, "But I'm still tired, I still can't sleep, I still can't eat." The doctor says, "It takes time, You've been through a lot, But you're healing." I say, "I don't know how much longer I can wait, I'm so tired of being tired, I'm so tired of being in pain." The doctor says, "I know, But you're doing better, You're getting stronger every day." I close my eyes and take a deep breath, I try to believe him, But it's hard. I want to be better, I want to be healed, But I don't know how much longer I can hold on. I open my eyes and look at the doctor, I say, "I'm trying, I'm really trying." The doctor smiles and says, "I know you are, And you'll get there." I don't know if I believe him, But I want to, So I nod and say, "Thank you." The doctor pats my arm and says, "You're welcome, Now go home and get some rest." I stand up and start to walk away, But then I turn around and say, "Doctor?" The doctor turns to me and says, "Yes?" I say, "Thank you for being here." The doctor smiles and says, "You're welcome, I'm glad I could help." I turn and walk away, I take a deep breath and start to walk down the hallway, I feel a little bit better, I know I'm not out of the woods yet, But I'm starting to believe that I'm going to be okay.

Title: Sleeping Trees
First Line: Between what should and what should not be Everything is liable to explode.
Whole Poem: Between what should and what should not be Everything is liable to explode. Many times I was told who has no land has no sea. My father Learned to fly in a dream. This is the story Of a sycamore tree he used to climb When he was young to watch the rain. Sometimes it rained so hard it hurt. Like being Beaten with sticks. Then the mud would run red. My brother believed bad dreams could kill A man in his sleep, he insisted We wake my father from his muffled screams On the night of the day he took us to see his village. No longer his village he found his tree amputated. Between one falling and the next There’﻿s a weightless state. There was a woman Who loved me. Asked me how to say tree In Arabic. I didn’﻿t tell her. She was sad. I didn’﻿t understand. When she left. I saw a man in my sleep three times. A man I knew Could turn anyone into one-half reptile. I was immune. I thought I was. I was terrified of being The only one left. When we woke my father He was running away from soldiers. Now He doesn’﻿t remember that night. He laughs About another sleep, he raised his arms to strike a king And tried not to stop. He flew But mother woke him and held him for an hour, Or half an hour, or as long as it takes a migration inward. Maybe if I had just said it. Shejerah, she would’﻿ve remembered me longer. Maybe I don’﻿t know much about dreams But my mother taught me the law of omen. The dead Know about the dying and sometimes Catch them in sleep like the sycamore tree My father used to climb When he was young to watch the rain stream, And he would gently swing.

The trees are dreaming of the earth, of the sky, of the sea. The trees are dreaming of the world, of the universe, of everything. The trees are dreaming of you, of me, of us all. The trees are dreaming of peace.

They are not supposed to be together. They are not supposed to be alive. But they are. And they are kissing. Their lips are brushing against each other Like the wings of a butterfly Against the petals of a flower. Their tongues are dancing together Like the waves of the sea Crashing against the shore. Their hearts are beating together Like the drums of war Thundering in the distance. Their souls are merging together Like the stars in the sky Twinkling in the darkness. They are not supposed to be there. They are not supposed to be together. They are not supposed to be alive. But they are. And they are kissing. And they are in love.

Title: Taking Back Jerusalem
First Line: Let me be brief: by the end of this, someone will be cursed
Whole Poem: Let me be brief: by the end of this, someone will be cursed & I pray it anyone but Him. Let me start again: the night was beautiful but not romantic. Sure, there was smoke & moon -light. From this angle, you could almost mistake the city for american. There were seven, all of us born of this country before this country existed. It was ours the way a street cat is mothered by thin air. Still, we called this a reclamation. A taking back: the sign reading cameras in use outside an unlit jewelry store, the palm trees dancing like they could belong here – city of gravel throat & temple’s cry – of gold -blessed forehead & confluenced histories – how many waters anointed & claimed you inheritance? How many hands un-sanctuaried you by birth -right & con -quest? A name, however holy can be a story of unimaginable distance. We could only exit you by the mouth through which we entered & there, we first saw Him: shadow folded in shadow speaking hushed & hurried Arabic & for the first time that night, a familiar I could but couldn’t have known: a boy with moonlit tongue promising his mother he’ll make it back with every breath – peering around the corner: a soldier, his gun, that precise small -ness – I couldn’t unsee him or Him, couldn’t uncast that smile from his nodding face, our mouths pretty with english – he stopped one of us. he searched only one of us. & there, I remembered my mother, begging God to watch over us in Jerusalem, where, at four years old, a soldier held a gun to her head & maybe it was or wasn’t at this exact spot, & maybe she prayed for the wrong son but in that moment, I prayed. & there was no God but the space between us – how the distance between my holy & His holy could resurrect a broken lord on my breath – & there I began to understand how my mother could abandon her birthright – & I suppose, she made it out. Alive, depending on your frame of reference. & so did we. & by some magic, so did that Boy, caught with the wrong God on His breath in His holy city. Forgive me. I’m trying to understand what makes one’s existence, at a fixed location, a radical act – divine even – & what makes the existence of another, near a specific body of water, a violence. Forgive me. I wrote this in an american airport & its magic escaped me.
Generation -- Title: **Taking Back Jerusalem** By George Abraham The call to prayer echoes through the streets, A reminder that this city is holy. For centuries, it has been fought over, But today, it is ours. We have taken back Jerusalem, The city of our dreams. We have returned to our rightful home, And we will never leave. We will rebuild this city, And make it a beacon of hope for all. We will show the world that peace is possible, And that love can conquer all. Jerusalem is ours, And we will never let it go. We will defend it with our lives, And we will pass it on to our children. Jerusalem is our home, And we will never give up. We will fight for it, And we will win. The call to prayer echoes through the streets, A reminder that this city is ours. We have taken back Jerusalem, And we will never let it go.

Title: Broken Ghazal, Before Balfour

Title: apology
First Line: it is the summer after my spleen almost ruptured into the stain of a thousand sunsets
Whole Poem: it is the summer after my spleen almost ruptured into the stain of a thousand sunsets: i am sitting in a therapist’s office & she asks me to start at the moment i wanted to die from my own hands: i could have painted her this body in all its failed topologies: i haven’t a home that isn’t in love with the way it floods: but instead, i gave her a history lesson: 1967 the west bank is annexed by israel after nakba: catastrophe: my grandparents: exile: in their own home: when i say, anxiety stretches continents: when i say depression is an ocean we never wanted to traverse: fast forward 1988: my aunt falls in love with a woman twice her age: finds mother in her after her own grieved a stolen country: decades of abuse from a husband with fists: in his blood: when she comes out they ask if she needs to see a therapist: a nice woman to excise this demon in her: fast forward today: a stranger with fists in his blood makes a growing country of my organs & i cannot love myself: or perhaps it was all a topology lesson: a stranger who cannot recognize me: tells the class of exact sequences: how topological spaces inherit the shape of their emptiness from previous generations of dimensions: a whole lineage of singularities: & at this point i too wanted to disappear: in the office of this therapist: who was perhaps a topologist: who asks me so what shape does this anxiety take inside of you? & i wanted to say tooth of a mouth: eye of a hurricane in my chest: organ with vast chambers haunted by their own empty: & so much blood it can almost be mistaken for a country: newfound inheritance: atheism found at the intersection of 3 merciless gods: do you pray still? why have you stopped praying? the therapist asks & perhaps the therapist is my mother: the one who found god at the bottom of liquor bottles the color of bloodied oceans: the hands that prayed for a son who left in search for home: desire, swelling in him like a ruptured organ: father, forgive me my drunk inheritance: forgive the stairs that collapsed beneath the weight of me: forgive the third floor window that tried to swallow me into the night’s mouth: forgive the bodies i swallowed like broken teeth: the knees i spent trying to summon god in my own mouth: forgive my DNA strands for they are sculptors of brief suicides in this body: i’m trying to love the shattered window of myself: the hands: the rocks: the broken religion left behind: my inheritance is a body of vandalized cathedrals: light me on fire: strip my god from my breath: watch as i dance amidst the flames:

Title: from The Spring Flowers Own: “The morning after / my death”
First Line: The morning after my death we will sit in cafés but I will not be there I will not be
Whole Poem: The morning after my death we will sit in cafés but I will not be there I will not be * There was the great death of birds the moon was consumed with fire the stars were visible until noon. Green was the forest drenched with shadows the roads were serpentine A redwood tree stood alone with its lean and lit body unable to follow the cars that went by with frenzy a tree is always an immutable traveller. The moon darkened at dawn the mountain quivered with anticipation and the ocean was double-shaded: the blue of its surface with the blue of flowers mingled in horizontal water trails there was a breeze to witness the hour * The sun darkened at the fifth hour of the day the beach was covered with conversations pebbles started to pour into holes and waves came in like horses. * The moon darkened on Christmas eve angels ate lemons in illuminated churches there was a blue rug planted with stars above our heads lemonade and war news competed for our attention our breath was warmer than the hills. * There was a great slaughter of rocks   of spring leaves of creeks the stars showed fully the last king of the Mountain gave battle and got killed. We lay on the grass covered dried blood with our bodies green blades swayed between our teeth. * We went out to sea a bank of whales was heading South a young man among us a hero tried to straddle one of the sea creatures his body emerged as a muddy pool as mud we waved goodbye to his remnants happy not to have to bury him in the early hours of the day We got drunk in a barroom the small town of Fairfax had just gone to bed cherry trees were bending under the weight of their flowers: they were involved in a ceremonial dance to which no one had ever been invited. * I know flowers to be funeral companions they make poisons and venoms and eat abandoned stone walls I know flowers shine stronger than the sun their eclipse means the end of times but I love flowers for their treachery their fragile bodies grace my imagination’s avenues without their presence my mind would be an unmarked grave. * We met a great storm at sea looked back at the rocking cliffs the sand was going under black birds were leaving the storm ate friends and foes alike water turned into salt for my wounds. * Flowers end in frozen patterns artificial gardens cover the floors we get up close to midnight search with powerful lights the tiniest shrubs on the meadows A stream desperately is running to the ocean *

Title: from The Manifestations of the Voyage
First Line: my house’s stairway is seized with vertigo. Matter having forsaken its laws, we land in hell, ascending to heaven.
Whole Poem: my house’s stairway is seized with vertigo. Matter having forsaken its laws, we land in hell, ascending to heaven. * Shadows move along ladders under the silence of ordinary things there is another silence: it belongs neither to the leaves nor to the dead with a crown of birds circling him a child is running in an abandoned house the stairway takes the measure of its own emptiness I myself am the stairway that Time has used in its funeral course wheels lift water in the gardens of Hama and come down not waiting for the river to put out the fire Here we are left with the river Seine and Paris’s poisons. I prefer gardens where linden trees get ready for a lunar voyage The stairway that separates my room from my memory whispers in my ear . . . I am not at the mercy of men since trees live in my fantasies men and trees long for fire and call for the rain I love rains which carry desires to oceans. Between one airplane and another space is disoriented stars sneak into holes and brides go naked to wells their innocence wanes under our eyes You and I are made from a worm-eaten wood The Word has sunk we are left with no cry   gesture or gaze silence to us is forbidden. We are threatened neither by life nor by death nor forced to admire the Spring I found earth-castles on the edge of the desert’s torrents I took their marble stairs but could not find my way either up or down then I understood that I was in a state of non-reason and non-madness and that the gardens of Andalusia were standing ready to die. * Two cities               Two tears Let insanity keep between its skirts legs within its black eyes the fright of my adolescence and the nocturnal walk on the hills: which hill? I mean the kingdom that a man carries in his gut when his love’s fulfilled. Two cities which are neither Beirut nor Damascus two tears: neither of alcohol nor of rain Yes there has been a truck and a blue-eyed woman from Russia —grey olive tree— I was a butterfly caught by a fire: neither the day’s not the night’s but the incandescence that radiates from the body like a receding sickness, Let tombs stay open! * The stairway which leads to my room borrows its metals from Babylon The Prophet’s Ascension had two movements we fell into whirlpools of mud and the wind followed his horse A tempest went after the sun’s steps The Prophet swam through waves of clouds a river of gold carried his vessel and away from the sun he reached Paradise a Paradise made of light. The stairway which leads to my room leads to an observatory I own two telescopes to observe stars and black holes and take mechanized stairs which advance with no advance my hair spins with sunflowers * Illegitimate is this linden tree which shakes by my door let us get ready for Hell! * Cursed be messengers tossing about water’s tranquility and building forest fences Oh that the wind go quicker than us! that we be smothered by light! This linden tree standing by my door weights heavy on my days I will finally marry it and we shall bring children condemned to terror this tree looks at me with insistence: It will be kept waiting until Time’s end.

Title: The New Colossus
First Line: Not like the brazen giant of Greek fame,
Whole Poem: Not like the brazen giant of Greek fame, With conquering limbs astride from land to land; Here at our sea-washed, sunset gates shall stand A mighty woman with a torch, whose flame Is the imprisoned lightning, and her name Mother of Exiles. From her beacon-hand Glows world-wide welcome; her mild eyes command The air-bridged harbor that twin cities frame. “Keep, ancient lands, your storied pomp!” cries she With silent lips. “Give me your tired, your poor, Your huddled masses yearning to breathe free, The wretched refuse of your teeming shore. Send these, the homeless, tempest-tost to me, I lift my lamp beside the golden door!”

Title: Long Island Sound
First Line: I see it as it looked one afternoon
Whole Poem: I see it as it looked one afternoon In August,— by a fresh soft breeze o’erblown. The swiftness of the tide, the light thereon, A far-off sail, white as a crescent moon. The shining waters with pale currents strewn, The quiet fishing-smacks, the Eastern cove, The semi-circle of its dark, green grove. The luminous grasses, and the merry sun In the grave sky; the sparkle far and wide, Laughter of unseen children, cheerful chirp Of crickets, and low lisp of rippling tide, Light summer clouds fantastical as sleep Changing unnoted while I gazed thereon. All these fair sounds and sights I made my own.
