She sees the people sleeping in their houses, and the animals grazing in the fields. She smiles, for she knows that she is the guardian of this land. She will protect it from harm, and she will watch over the people who live here. The panther of the heavens is a symbol of strength and beauty. She is a reminder that we are all connected to the natural world, and that we must respect the land that we live on. When you see the panther of the heavens, know that she is watching over you. She is a sign of hope and promise, and she reminds us that we are all part of something larger than ourselves.

Title: The Country Clown
First Line: Bred in distant woods, the clown Brings all his country airs to town;
Whole Poem: Bred in distant woods, the clown Brings all his country airs to town; The odd address, with awkward grace, That bows with half-averted face; The half-heard compliments, whose note Is swallow'd in the trembling throat; The stiffen'd gait, the drawling tone, By which his native place is known; The blush, that looks by vast degrees, Too much like modesty to please; The proud displays of awkward dress, That all the country fop express: The suit right gay, though much belated, Whose fashion's superannuated; The watch, depending far in state, Whose iron chain might form a grate; The silver buckle, dread to view, O'ershadowing all the clumsy shoe; The white-gloved hand, that tries to peep From ruffle, full five inches deep; With fifty odd affairs beside, The foppishness of country pride. Poor Dick! though first thy airs provoke The obstreperous laugh and scornful joke Doom'd all the ridicule to stand, While each gay dunce shall lend a hand; Yet let not scorn dismay thy hope To shine a witling and a fop. Blest impudence the prize shall gain, And bid thee sigh no more in vain. Thy varied dress shall quickly show At once the spendthrift and the beau. With pert address and noisy tongue, That scorns the fear of prating wrong 'Mongst listening coxcombs shalt thou shine, And every voice shall echo thine.

Title: To A Young Lady
First Line: In vain, fair Maid, you ask in vain, My pen should try th' advent'rous strain,
Whole Poem: In vain, fair Maid, you ask in vain, My pen should try th' advent'rous strain, And following truth's unalter'd law, Attempt your character to draw. I own indeed, that generous mind That weeps the woes of human kind, That heart by friendship's charms inspired, That soul with sprightly fancy fired, The air of life, the vivid eye, The flowing wit, the keen reply— To paint these beauties as they shine, Might ask a nobler pen than mine. Yet what sure strokes can draw the Fair, Who vary, like the fleeting air, Like willows bending to the force, Where'er the gales direct their course, Opposed to no misfortune's power, And changing with the changing hour. Now gaily sporting on the plain, They charm the grove with pleasing strain; Anon disturb'd, they know not why, The sad tear trembles in their eye: Led through vain life's uncertain dance, The dupes of whim, the slaves of chance. From me, not famed for much goodnature, Expect not compliment, but satire; To draw your picture quite unable, Instead of fact accept a Fable. One morn, in Æsop's noisy time, When all things talk'd, and talk'd in rhyme, A cloud exhaled by vernal beams Rose curling o'er the glassy streams. The dawn her orient blushes spread, And tinged its lucid skirts with red, Wide waved its folds with glitt'ring dies, And gaily streak'd the eastern skies; Beneath, illumed with rising day, The sea's broad mirror floating lay. Pleased, o'er the wave it hung in air, Survey'd its glittering glories there, And fancied, dress'd in gorgeous show, Itself the brightest thing below: For clouds could raise the vaunting strain, And not the fair alone were vain. Yet well it knew, howe'er array'd, That beauty, e'en in clouds, might fade, That nothing sure its charms could boast Above the loveliest earthly toast; And so, like them, in early dawn Resolved its picture should be drawn, That when old age with length'ning day Should brush the vivid rose away, The world should from the portrait own Beyond all clouds how bright it shone. Hard by, a painter raised his stage, Far famed, the Copley[1] of his age. So just a form his colours drew, Each eye the perfect semblance knew; Yet still on every blooming face He pour'd the pencil's flowing grace; Each critic praised the artist rare, Who drew so like, and yet so fair. To him, high floating in the sky Th' elated Cloud advanced t' apply. The painter soon his colours brought, The Cloud then sat, the artist wrought; Survey'd her form, with flatt'ring strictures, Just as when ladies sit for pictures, Declared "whatever art can do, My utmost skill shall try for you: But sure those strong and golden dies Dipp'd in the radiance of the skies, Those folds of gay celestial dress, No mortal colours can express. Not spread triumphal o'er the plain, The rainbow boasts so fair a train, Nor e'en the morning sun so bright, Who robes his face in heav'nly light. To view that form of angel make, Again Ixion would mistake, And justly deem so fair a prize, The sovereign Mistress of the skies," He said, and drew a mazy line, With crimson touch his pencils shine, The mingling colours sweetly fade, And justly temper light and shade. He look'd; the swelling Cloud on high With wider circuit spread the sky, Stretch'd to the sun an ampler train, And pour'd new glories on the main. As quick, effacing every ground, His pencil swept the canvas round, And o'er its field, with magic art, Call'd forth new forms in every part. But now the sun, with rising ray, Advanced with speed his early way; Each colour takes a differing die, The orange glows, the purples fly. The artist views the alter'd sight, And varies with the varying light; In vain! a sudden gust arose, New folds ascend, new shades disclose, And sailing on with swifter pace, The Cloud displays another face. In vain the painter, vex'd at heart, Tried all the wonders of his art; In vain he begg'd, her form to grace, One moment she would keep her place: For, "changing thus with every gale, Now gay with light, with gloom now pale, Now high in air with gorgeous train, Now settling on the darken'd main, With looks more various than the moon; A French coquette were drawn as soon." He spoke; again the air was mild, The Cloud with opening radiance smiled; With canvas new his art he tries, Anew he joins the glitt'ring dies; Th' admiring Cloud with pride beheld Her image deck the pictured field, And colours half-complete adorn The splendor of the painted morn. When lo, the stormy winds arise, Deep gloom invests the changing skies; The sounding tempest shakes the plain, And lifts in billowy surge the main. The Cloud's gay dies in darkness fade, Its folds condense in thicker shade, And borne by rushing blasts, its form With lowering vapour joins the storm.
Generation -- Title: To A Young Lady By John Trumbull When lovely woman stoops to folly, And finds too late that men betray, What charm can soothe her melancholy? What art can wash her guilt away? The only art her guilt to cover, To hide her shame from every eye, To give repentance to her lover, And win his love, she must die. And die she will, if she is true, And leave a lover to deplore, And weep the ashes of her beauty, And curse the day he saw her more. But if she lives, to joy she'll run, And leave the lover to deplore, And weep the ashes of her beauty, And curse the day he saw her more.
Generation -- Firstline Only: To paint the charms of your fair face, Or sing the virtues of your mind. For how can words, whose feeble sounds Are but the breath of empty air, Hope to express the matchless grace That dwells within your heav'nly eyes? Or paint the soft and melting blush That mantles on your cheek like dawn? Or tell the sweet and gentle smile That lights your face like summer's sun? No, fairest Maid, my feeble art Can never hope to do you justice; For you are like the radiant stars, That far outshine the feeble light Of mortal eyes; or like the flowers, That breathe their fragrance on the air, And fill the heart with joy and gladness. And so I leave you, fairest Maid, To the care of gentle Fancy, Who will, I doubt not, do you more justice Than my rude pen can ever hope to do.

Title: The Owl And The Sparrow
First Line: In elder days, in Saturn's prime, Ere baldness seized the head of Time,
Whole Poem: In elder days, in Saturn's prime, Ere baldness seized the head of Time, While truant Jove, in infant pride, Play'd barefoot on Olympus' side, Each thing on earth had power to chatter, And spoke the mother tongue of nature. Each stock or stone could prate and gabble, Worse than ten labourers of Babel. Along the street, perhaps you'd see A Post disputing with a Tree, And mid their arguments of weight, A Goose sit umpire of debate. Each Dog you met, though speechless now, Would make his compliments and bow, And every Swine with congees come, To know how did all friends at home. Each Block sublime could make a speech, In style and eloquence as rich, And could pronounce it and could pen it, As well as Chatham in the senate. Nor prose alone.—In these young times, Each field was fruitful too in rhymes; Each feather'd minstrel felt the passion, And every wind breathed inspiration. Each Bullfrog croak'd in loud bombastic, Each Monkey chatter'd Hudibrastic; Each Cur, endued with yelping nature, Could outbark Churchill's self in satire; Each Crow in prophecy delighted, Each Owl, you saw, was second-sighted, Each Goose a skilful politician, Each Ass a gifted met'physician, Could preach in wrath 'gainst laughing rogues, Write Halfway-covenant Dialogues, And wisely judge of all disputes In commonwealths of men or brutes. 'Twas then, in spring a youthful Sparrow Felt the keen force of Cupid's arrow: For Birds, as Æsop's tales avow, Made love then, just as men do now, And talk'd of deaths and flames and darts, And breaking necks and losing hearts; And chose from all th' aerial kind, Not then to tribes, like Jews, confined The story tells, a lovely Thrush Had smit him from a neigh'bring bush, Where oft the young coquette would play, And carol sweet her siren lay: She thrill'd each feather'd heart with love, And reign'd the Toast of all the grove. He felt the pain, but did not dare Disclose his passion to the fair; For much he fear'd her conscious pride Of race, to noble blood allied. Her grandsire's nest conspicuous stood, Mid loftiest branches of the wood, In airy height, that scorn'd to know Each flitting wing that waved below. So doubting, on a point so nice He deem'd it best to take advice. Hard by there dwelt an aged Owl, Of all his friends the gravest fowl; Who from the cares of business free, Lived, hermit, in a hollow tree; To solid learning bent his mind, In trope and syllogism he shined, 'Gainst reigning follies spent his railing; Too much a Stoic—'twas his failing. Hither for aid our Sparrow came, And told his errand and his name, With panting breath explain'd his case, Much trembling at the sage's face; And begg'd his Owlship would declare If love were worth a wise one's care. The grave Owl heard the weighty cause, And humm'd and hah'd at every pause; Then fix'd his looks in sapient plan, Stretch'd forth one foot, and thus began. "My son, my son, of love beware, And shun the cheat of beauty's snare; That snare more dreadful to be in, Than huntsman's net, or horse-hair gin. "By others' harms learn to be wise," As ancient proverbs well advise. Each villany, that nature breeds, From females and from love proceeds. 'Tis love disturbs with fell debate Of man and beast the peaceful state: Men fill the world with war's alarms, When female trumpets sound to arms; The commonwealth of dogs delight For beauties, as for bones, to fight. Love hath his tens of thousands slain, And heap'd with copious death the plain: Samson, with ass's jaw to aid, Ne'er peopled thus th'infernal shade. "Nor this the worst; for he that's dead, With love no more will vex his head. 'Tis in the rolls of fate above, That death's a certain cure for love; A noose can end the cruel smart; The lover's leap is from a cart. But oft a living death they bear, Scorn'd by the proud, capricious fair. The fair to sense pay no regard, And beauty is the fop's reward; They slight the generous hearts' esteem, And sigh for those, who fly from them. Just when your wishes would prevail, Some rival bird with gayer tail, Who sings his strain with sprightlier note, And chatters praise with livelier throat, Shall charm your flutt'ring fair one down, And leave your choice, to hang or drown. Ev'n I, my son, have felt the smart; A Pheasant won my youthful heart. For her I tuned the doleful lay, For her I watch'd the night away; In vain I told my piteous case, And smooth'd my dignity of face; In vain I cull'd the studied phrase, And sought hard words in beauty's praise. Her, not my charms nor sense could move, For folly is the food of love. Each female scorns our serious make, "Each woman is at heart a rake." Thus Owls in every age have said, Since our first parent-owl was made; Thus Pope and Swift, to prove their sense, Shall sing, some twenty ages hence; Then shall a man of little fame, One * sing the same.
Generation -- Firstline Only: And Love was young, and Beauty bright, And Nature wore a fresher guise, The Seasons four, in fair array, With dance and song came trooping by, And Winter led the merry way. He sang of storms, and clouds, and snow, And all the pleasures of the cold, And hailstones dancing in the air, And winds that whistled loud and bold. And Spring came next, a lovely maid, With flowers and birds in her array, And gentle winds and sunny skies, And soft warm rains that gently fall. And Summer followed in her train, With fruits and flowers and golden grain, And glowing skies, and warm bright days, And nights when moonlight silvered all. And last came Autumn, rich and gay, In purple robes and golden crown, With harvest-fields that waved in gold, And forests changing to russet brown. And still the Seasons come and go, With dance and song, as long ago, And still the earth is fair and bright, And still the sun shines on in light.

Title: Beneath A Mountain's Brow
First Line: Beneath a mountain's brow, the most remote And inaccessible by Shepherds trod,
Whole Poem: Beneath a mountain's brow, the most remote And inaccessible by Shepherds trod, In a deep cave, dug by no mortals hands An Hermit lived,—a melancholy man Who was the wonder of our wand'ring swains: Austere and lonely—cruel to himself They did report him—the cold earth his bed, Water his drink, his food the Shepherd's alms. I went to see him, and my heart was touched With reverence and pity. Mild he spake, And entering on discourse, such stories told, As made me oft re-visit his sad cell.
Generation -- Title: Beneath a Mountain's Brow Beneath a mountain's brow, Where the cliffs are steep and high, And the winds are loud and shrill, And the eagles soar on high, There dwelt a youth, whose heart Was full of love and truth; And he loved a maid, whose eyes Were bright as summer skies. But the maid was proud and cold, And she scorned the youth's love; And she said, "I will not wed A shepherd boy like you." The youth was sad and sighing, And he wandered far away; And he came to a land of strangers, And he learned to fight and slay. And he fought in many battles, And he won many a crown; And he became a mighty warrior, And his name was known throughout the land. But he never forgot the maid, Whose eyes were bright as summer skies; And he dreamed of her in the day, And he dreamed of her at night. And one day, he returned to his home, And he sought the maid; And he found her, and he wooed her, And she yielded to his love. And they were married, and they lived happily ever after, In a cottage beneath a mountain's brow.
Generation -- Firstline: Beneath a mountain's brow, the most remote And inaccessible by Shepherds trod, There dwelt a youth, who loved to roam the wood, And meditate on Nature's works alone. He saw the sun rise o'er the mountain's top, And sink beneath the waves of ocean blue; He saw the moonbeams dance upon the lake, And heard the music of the waterfall. He watched the clouds float through the sky, And listened to the wind as it sighed among the trees; He saw the flowers bloom in the spring, And the leaves fall in the autumn. He loved to wander through the forest, And gather the wild flowers that grew there; He loved to listen to the birds sing, And watch the squirrels play among the branches. He loved to lie on the grass, and gaze up at the sky, And think of the great Creator who made it all. He was a happy youth, and he loved to live in the woods; But one day he met a beautiful maiden, And his heart was filled with love. He asked the maiden to marry him, And she said yes. They were married in a little church in the village, And they lived happily ever after.
Generation -- Firstline Only: An ancient pile, whose hoary battlements, And mouldering towers, the ivy's dark embrace, And clustering shrubs, invest with solemn grace. 2 There, in a vault, whose entrance is concealed By clustering ivy, and whose gloomy cells Are never pierced by the sun's cheering ray, A youth, whose form and features might beguile A sculptor's eye, and fill his soul with joy, Sat musing on the days of long ago. 3 He thought of days when, in his father's hall, He was the pride and joy of every heart; When all his words were listened to with awe, And all his actions watched with tenderest care. 4 But now, alas! his father's house is gone, And he, a lonely wanderer, roams the earth, Seeking a home, but finding none on earth. 5 He thought of her, the fairest of the fair, Who shared his joys and sorrows, and whose love Was like a light, that cheered him through the gloom Of life's dark path. 6 But she is gone, and he is left alone, A lonely wanderer on the earth. 7 He thought of death, and how it would release him From all his sorrows, and his soul would fly To join the spirits of the blest on high. 8 Then, with a sigh, he rose, and left the vault, And wandered forth into the moonlight night.

Title: Lines To Grief
First Line: COME Grief, and sing a solemn dirge Beneath this midnight shade;
Whole Poem: COME Grief, and sing a solemn dirge Beneath this midnight shade; From central darkness now emerge, And tread the lonely glade. This is the cheerless hour of night, For sorrow only made; When no intrusive rays of light, The silent gloom pervade. Though such the darkness of my soul, Not such the calmness there; But waves of guilt tumultuous roll 'Midst billows of despair. Fallacious Pleasure's tinsel train My soul rejects with scorn; If higher joys she can't attain, She'd rather choose to mourn. For bliss superior she was made; Or for extreme despair; If pain awaits her past the dead, Why should she triumph here? Tho' Reason points at good supreme, Yet Grace must lead us thence Must wake us from this pleasing dream, The idle joys of Sense. Surely I wish the blackest night Of Nature to remain, Till Christ arise with healing light, Then welcome day again.
Generation -- Title: Lines To Grief By Ann Eliza Bleecker Grief, thou art a fiend, With a heart of ice, And a poison-breathing breath; Thou dost tear the soul With thy piercing dart, And thy presence is death. Thou dost haunt the lonely heart, And the desolate home; Thou dost sit by the sick bed, And fan the flame of pain; Thou dost follow the funeral train, And mock the mourner's woe; Thou art the shadow of death, And the darkness of the grave. But thou art not eternal; Thy power shall pass away; The light of joy shall return, And the song of gladness be heard; The tears of sorrow shall be wiped away, And the heart shall be at peace. Then, Grief, thou shalt be forgotten, And thy name shall be a hissing; The memory of thy deeds shall be a curse, And thy reign of terror shall be no more.
Generation -- Firstline: COME, Grief, and sing a solemn dirge Beneath this midnight shade; Let each sad note be deeply fraught With anguish and despair. The moon is hid behind the clouds, The stars are dim and pale; The wind is moaning through the trees, And all is drear and desolate. Oh, Death! thou art a welcome guest To him whose heart is breaking; For thou dost bring him sweet relief From all his earthly pain. Come, Death, and take me from this world Of sorrow and of sin; And lead me to that happy land Where all is peace and love. I hear the sound of angel's wings, I see the gates of heaven; Oh, Death, I come, I come! I hasten to thy call.
Generation -- Firstline Only: Let sorrow's dark and heavy wing O'erwhelm the mournful maid. Her lover's dead, and cold, and pale, No more to cheer her heart; His voice is hushed, his eyes are closed, And he is laid in the mouldering earth. Oh, Grief! thou art a cruel guest, Whose presence rends the soul; But yet I welcome thee, though pain Be all the gift thou bring'st to me. For thou wilt lead me to the grave, Where I shall rest with him I love; And then, perhaps, our spirits may Together meet in heaven above.

Title: An Evening Prospect
First Line: COME, my Susan, quit your chamber, Greet the opening bloom of May,
Whole Poem: COME, my Susan, quit your chamber, Greet the opening bloom of May, Let us up yon hillock clamber, And around the scene survey. See the sun is now descending, And projects his shadows far, And the bee her course is bending Homeward through the humid air. Mark the lizard just before us, Singing her unvaried strain, While the frog abrupt in chorus Deepens through the marshy plain. From yon grove the woodcock rises, Mark her progress by her notes, High in air her wing she poises, Then like lightning down she shoots. Now the whip-poor-will beginning, Clamorous on a pointed rail, Drowns the more melodious singing Of the catbird, thrush, and quail. Pensive Echo from the mountain Still repeats the sylvan sounds; And the crocus-bordered fountain With the splendid fly abounds. There the honey-suckle blooming, Reddens the capricious wave; Richer sweets, the air perfuming, Spicy Ceylon never gave. Cast your eyes beyond this meadow, Painted by a hand divine, And observe the ample shadow Of that solemn ridge of pine. Here a trickling rill depending, Glitters through the artless bower And the silver dew descending, Doubly radiates every flower. While I speak, the sun is vanish'd, All the gilded clouds are fled; Music from the groves is banish'd, Noxious vapours round us spread. Rural toil is now suspended, Sleep invades the peasant's eyes; Each diurnal task is ended, While soft Luna climbs the skies. Queen of rest and meditation! Through thy medium, I adore Him— the Author of creation, Infinite and boundless power! He now fills thy urn with glory, Transcript of immortal light; Lord! my spirit bows before thee, Lost in wonder and delight.
Generation -- Title: An Evening Prospect How sweetly sleep the evening clouds away, While soft'ning sunbeams gild the closing day! The birds, that chirped so cheerily before, Have hush'd their songs, and seek the silent shore. The busy winds have hush'd their noisy wing, And o'er the landscape gently seem to sing A lullaby, to lull the world to rest; While balmy zephyrs breathe a sweet caress. The waves, that danced upon the wat'ry plain, Now gently heave, and break in murmurs faint; And as they die away, methinks I hear The spirits of the deep breathe low and clear. The trees, that waved their branches to the breeze, Now stand in silence, like a pensive train; And as I gaze upon their stately forms, I think of those who once were like to them. They flourish'd in their youth, and deck'd the plain With beauty, like the trees that now I see; But they are gone, and left no trace behind, Save in the memory of the passer-by. So man, when life's brief summer days are o'er, Shall leave no trace behind, save in the mind; And those who come shall wonder at his worth, And mourn that he is gone, and ne'er return.
Generation -- Firstline: COME, my Susan, quit your chamber, Greet the opening bloom of May; See the birds on every spray Warble forth their songs of joy. Hark! the wood-lark's tender voice Hails the morning's early dawn; While the lark, on airy wing, Soars to meet the rising sun. Come, my Susan, let us haste To the fields and verdant groves; Where the zephyrs gently play, And the bees their sweets disclose. There amid the fragrant flowers We will sit and talk of love; While the birds shall chant around Their melodious songs of joy. Come, my Susan, let us haste To the fields and verdant groves; Where the zephyrs gently play, And the bees their sweets disclose.
Generation -- Firstline Only: Come and view the fields so charming, Where the lambkins frisk and play. Come and view the violets blue, Blooming on the sunny hill, Come and view the daisies too, Peeping from the dewy grass. Come and view the primroses gay, Peeping from the mossy bank, Come and view the cowslips gay, Dancing in the summer breeze. Come and view the buttercups bright, Shining in the morning sun, Come and view the daisies white, Dancing in the summer breeze. Come and view the hawthorn bush, Laden with its fragrant flowers, Come and view the woodbine too, Twining round the mossy bower. Come and view the wild rose gay, Blooming in the sunny glade, Come and view the eglantine too, Blooming in the summer breeze. Come and view the summer sky, Painted with the rainbow's hues, Come and view the setting sun, Gilding the western clouds. Come and view the evening star, Shining in the twilight sky, Come and view the moon so bright, Riding in the midnight air. Come and view the early dawn, Breaking on the eastern hills, Come and view the morning dew, Sparkling on the grass and flowers. Come and view the beauties of nature, In the opening bloom of May, Come and view the works of God, And praise Him for His love.

Title: Hymn
First Line: JESUS CHRIST! regard my anguish, Oh! commiserate my pain;
Whole Poem: JESUS CHRIST! regard my anguish, Oh! commiserate my pain; Bid my soul no longer languish, Bid my spirit not complain. 'T is my comfort thou'rt omniscient, All my griefs are known to thee, Saviour! thou art all sufficient, To relieve a wretch like me. Now thy clemency discover, Give my wounded soul repose, E'er my transient life is over, E'er my sorrowing eyelids close. By thy passion I conjure thee, By thy painful sweat of blood, Let my sighing come before thee, Seal my pardon now with God.
Generation -- Title: **Hymn** By Ann Eliza Bleecker How sweet the name of Jesus sounds In a believer's ear! It soothes his sorrows, heals his wounds, And drives away his fear. It makes the darkness bright, The dreariest day seem bright; It turns the bitterest pain Into a joy again. O Jesus, precious Jesus! How can I love thee enough? My heart with love to thee is filled, And yet I love thee not enough. I love thee for thy dying love, For thy redeeming blood; I love thee for thy tender care, Thy goodness and thy truth. I love thee for thy patience, Thy meekness, and thy love; I love thee for thy great compassion, Thy tender heart above. O Jesus, precious Jesus! How can I love thee enough? My heart with love to thee is filled, And yet I love thee not enough. I love thee for thy promises, Thy sure and certain word; I love thee for thy heavenly home, Where all thy saints are stored. I love thee for thy presence, Which makes my heart rejoice; I love thee for thy love, Which will forever never cease. O Jesus, precious Jesus! How can I love thee enough? My heart with love to thee is filled, And yet I love thee not enough.
Generation -- Firstline: JESUS CHRIST! regard my anguish, Oh! commiserate my pain; For I am weak, and thou art strong, And thou wilt save me from my sin. I have sinned against thee, O Lord, And I am filled with shame and fear; But I repent of my sin, And I trust in thy mercy. Oh, cleanse me from my sin, And make me pure in thy sight; For I desire to be thy child, And to live in thy love. I know that thou art a merciful God, And that thou wilt forgive me my sin; And I thank thee for thy love, Which is greater than my sin. I will not sin again, O Lord, But I will live in thy love; And I will serve thee with all my heart, And I will praise thy name forever. Amen.
Generation -- Firstline Only: Behold me, prostrate at thy feet, O! hear my humble prayer. I have offended thee, O Lord! I know my sins are great; But, through thy grace, I trust to be Forgiven, and saved at last. O! cleanse my soul from every stain, And make me pure within; Then shall I stand before thy throne, A child of light, and not of sin. O! Jesus, I believe in thee, I love thee with my heart; I trust in thy redeeming blood, To cleanse me from all my guilt. O! let me feel thy presence near, And guide me all my life; Then shall I walk in peace and joy, And find my home in heaven above.

Title: Return To Tomhanick
First Line: HAIL, happy shades! though clad with heavy snows,
Whole Poem: HAIL, happy shades! though clad with heavy snows, At sight of you with joy my bosom glows; Ye arching pines, that bow with every breeze, Ye poplars, elms, all hail! my well-known trees! And now my peaceful mansion strikes my eye, And now the tinkling rivulet I spy; My little garden, Flora, hast thou kept, And watch'd my pinks and lilies, while I wept? Or has the grubbing swine, by furies led, The enclosure broke, and on my flowrets fed? Ah me! that spot with blooms so lately grac'd, With storms and driving snows, is now defaced; Sharp icicles from every bush depend, And frosts all dazzling o'er the beds extend: Yet soon fair spring shall give another scene, And yellow cowslips gild the level green; My little orchard sprouting at each bough, Fragrant with clustering blossoms deep shall glow: Ah! then 't is sweet the tufted grass to tread, But sweeter slumbering is the balmy shade; The rapid humming-bird, with ruby breast, Seeks the parterre with early blue-bells drest, Drinks deep the honeysuckle dew, or drives The labouring bee to her domestic hives: Then shines the lupine bright with morning gems, And sleepy poppies nod upon their stems; The humble violet, and the dulcet rose, The stately lily then, and tulip blows. Farewell, my Plutarch! farewell, pen and muse! Nature exults —shall I her call refuse? Apollo fervid glitters in my face, And threatens with his beam each feeble grace: Yet still around the lovely plants I toil, And draw obnoxious herbage from the soil; Or with the lime-twigs little birds surprise; Or angle for the trout of many dyes. But when the vernal breezes pass away, And loftier Phoebus darts a fiercer ray, The spiky corn then rattles all around, And dashing cascades give a pleasing sound; Shrill sings the locust with prolonged note, The cricket chirps familiar in each cot. The village children, rambling o'er yon hill, With berries all their painted baskets fill. They rob the squirrel's little walnut store, And climb the half-exhausted tree for more; Or else to fields of maze nocturnal hie, Where hid, the elusive water-melons lie; Sportive, they make incisions in the rind, The riper from the immature to find; Then load their tender shoulders with the prey, And laughing, bear the bulky fruit away.
Generation -- Title: Return To Tomhanick By Ann Eliza Bleecker Return, ye long-lost scenes of childhood, Return, ye days of joy and love! Once more I tread your flowery wilds, And breathe the freshness of the grove. The birds that sang me to my slumber, Still charm the forest with their song; The brook that babbled by my side, Still wanders on with murmuring song. The rocks that sheltered me from danger, Still lift their heads against the sky; The trees that shaded me from the sun, Still spread their branches to the sky. But all is changed, alas! to me; The friends I loved are gone away; The joys I cherished are no more; And I am left alone to stray. Yet still I love to wander here, And breathe the air that once I breathed; For here my heart can find repose, And every scene recalls the past. Oh, Tomhanick! thou art still my home, Though other scenes may be more fair; For here my childhood's days were passed, And here my heart will ever rest.
Generation -- Firstline: HAIL, happy shades! though clad with heavy snows, And darkly frowning in the face of day, Your charms are still divine, your beauties glow With unextinguishable fire. When summer's sun exhales his sultry breath, And sultry summer spreads her baneful reign, Your cool retreats invite the weary swain, And grateful he inhales your freshening air. When winter's storms deform the face of nature, And angry winds disturb the liquid plain, Your calm retreats afford the pensive mind A safe asylum from the storm without. Here, while the storm without disturbs the air, And angry waves lash the resounding shore, I sit and view the tempest from afar, And think of all the dangers I have passed. I think of all the dangers I have passed, And bless the hand that led me safe ashore; I think of all the friends I've left behind, And mourn the loss of those I hold most dear. But still I feel a secret joy within, A joy that nothing can destroy; The joy of knowing that I'm still alive, And that I'm still loved by those who know me best. So hail, ye happy shades! though clad with snows, Your charms are still divine, your beauties glow; And while I live, I'll ever hold you dear, The scenes of my childhood, the home of my youth.
Generation -- Firstline Only: Hail, happy shades! though clad in heavy snows, Ye wilds of Windermere, where Power divine Hath made his dwelling, ever holy ground! Though rude and desolate your charms may be, To me your peace is dear, your storms are kind. I love your rocks, which, wild and bare and high, Lift their dark summits to the stormy sky; I love your woods, whose thick and gloomy shades, Where scarce a sunbeam peeps, extend around; I love your torrents, roaring down the steep, And dashing on the rocks their snowy foam; I love your lakes, whose dark and glassy waves Reflect the clouds and mountains, and the sky; I love your mists, that, rising from the ground, In silent majesty invest the scene; And, last, I love your storms, whose thundering voice, And vivid lightnings, speak the power of God. Hail, happy shades! though clad in heavy snows, Ye wilds of Windermere, where Power divine Hath made his dwelling, ever holy ground!

Title: The Inward Morning
First Line: Packed in my mind lie all the clothes Which outward nature wears,
Whole Poem: Packed in my mind lie all the clothes Which outward nature wears, And in its fashion's hourly change It all things else repairs. In vain I look for change abroad, And can no difference find, Till some new ray of peace uncalled Illumes my inmost mind. What is it gilds the trees and clouds, And paints the heavens so gay, But yonder fast-abiding light With its unchanging ray? Lo, when the sun streams through the wood, Upon a winter's morn, Where'er his silent beams intrude, The murky night is gone. How could the patient pine have known The morning breeze would come, Or humble flowers anticipate The insect's noonday hum-- Till the new light with morning cheer From far streamed through the aisles, And nimbly told the forest trees For many stretching miles? I've heard within my inmost soul Such cheerful morning news, In the horizon of my mind Have seen such orient hues, As in the twilight of the dawn, When the first birds awake, Are heard within some silent wood, Where they the small twigs break, Or in the eastern skies are seen, Before the sun appears, The harbingers of summer heats Which from afar he bears.
Generation -- Title: The Inward Morning By Henry David Thoreau The inward morning, My private sunrise, My springtime's damask morning, Hast thou dawned on me? The inward morning, My invisible April, My greening and flowery April, Hast thou dawned on me? The inward morning, My blue-bird morning, My morning of robins and bluebirds, Hast thou dawned on me? The inward morning, My morning of winds, My morning of clouds, Hast thou dawned on me? The inward morning, My morning of stars, My morning of sun, Hast thou dawned on me? The inward morning, My morning of light, My morning of joy, Hast thou dawned on me?
Generation -- Firstline Only: And in its fashion's hourly change It seemeth wisest to me. I care not what the tailors say, The fashion of my mind is made; I wear the fashions of to-day, But next year's are in my trade.

Title: I Was Made Erect and Lone
First Line: I was made erect and lone, And within me is the bone;
Whole Poem: I was made erect and lone, And within me is the bone; Still my vision will be clear, Still my life will not be drear, To the center all is near. Where I sit there is my throne. If age choose to sit apart, If age choose, give me the start, Take the sap and leave the heart.
Generation -- Title: I was made erect and lone, That I might turn and see All sides of heaven and of earth, And see all sights distinctly. I was made erect and lone, That I might stand and view Ocean and land, and rise in thought To heaven above.
Generation -- Firstline: I was made erect and lone, And within me is the bone; I stand and look out upon the world, And think of what is to be done. I am the voice of the people, I am the voice of the trees, I am the voice of the mountains, I am the voice of the sea. I am the voice of the future, I am the voice of the past, I am the voice of the present, I am the voice of all. I am the one who sees, I am the one who hears, I am the one who feels, I am the one who knows. I am the one who speaks, I am the one who acts, I am the one who creates, I am the one who changes the world. I am the one who is, I am the one who will be, I am the one who has been, I am the one who always is.

Title: The Summer Rain
First Line: My books I'd fain cast off, I cannot read,
Whole Poem: My books I'd fain cast off, I cannot read, 'Twixt every page my thoughts go stray at large Down in the meadow, where is richer feed, And will not mind to hit their proper targe. Plutarch was good, and so was Homer too, Our Shakespeare's life were rich to live again, What Plutarch read, that was not good nor true, Nor Shakespeare's books, unless his books were men. Here while I lie beneath this walnut bough, What care I for the Greeks or for Troy town, If juster battles are enacted now Between the ants upon this hummock's crown? Bid Homer wait till I the issue learn, If red or black the gods will favor most, Or yonder Ajax will the phalanx turn, Struggling to heave some rock against the host. Tell Shakespeare to attend some leisure hour, For now I've business with this drop of dew, And see you not, the clouds prepare a shower-- I'll meet him shortly when the sky is blue. This bed of herd's grass and wild oats was spread Last year with nicer skill than monarchs use. A clover tuft is pillow for my head, And violets quite overtop my shoes. And now the cordial clouds have shut all in, And gently swells the wind to say all's well; The scattered drops are falling fast and thin, Some in the pool, some in the flower-bell. I am well drenched upon my bed of oats; But see that globe come rolling down its stem, Now like a lonely planet there it floats, And now it sinks into my garment's hem. Drip drip the trees for all the country round, And richness rare distills from every bough; The wind alone it is makes every sound, Shaking down crystals on the leaves below. For shame the sun will never show himself, Who could not with his beams e'er melt me so; My dripping locks--they would become an elf, Who in a beaded coat does gayly go.
Generation -- Firstline: My books I'd fain cast off, I cannot read, My eyes they rove about the dreamy street; The clouds are bright, the air is fresh and sweet, The wind is rustling with a sound like feet. I hear the birds, I see the waving trees, I feel the sunshine, and I long to be A part of all things; free as they are free, A part of Nature, not a man apart. My books are dead, they cannot understand The yearning of my soul, the joy, the pain; They cannot see the beauty of the land, The wonder of the sky, the love of man. I close my books and leave them on the shelf, And go out into the open world to live; To feel the life that stirs in every leaf, To drink the sunshine, and to taste the rain. I am a part of Nature, and she is a part of me; We are one, and we shall never be apart.

Title: Sic Vita
First Line: I am a parcel of vain strivings tied
Whole Poem: I am a parcel of vain strivings tied By a chance bond together, Dangling this way and that, their links Were made so loose and wide, Methinks, For milder weather. A bunch of violets without their roots, And sorrel intermixed, Encircled by a wisp of straw Once coiled about their shoots, The law By which I'm fixed. A nosegay which Time clutched from out Those fair Elysian fields, With weeds and broken stems, in haste, Doth make the rabble rout That waste The day he yields. And here I bloom for a short hour unseen, Drinking my juices up, With no root in the land To keep my branches green, But stand In a bare cup. Some tender buds were left upon my stem In mimicry of life, But ah! the children will not know, Till time has withered them, The woe With which they're rife. But now I see I was not plucked for naught, And after in life's vase Of glass set while I might survive, But by a kind hand brought Alive To a strange place. That stock thus thinned will soon redeem its hours, And by another year, Such as God knows, with freer air, More fruits and fairer flowers Will bear, While I droop here.
Generation -- Title: Sic Vita Sic Vita So goes life. The morning breaks, And we step into the dew, And are refreshed. The evening comes, And we go to our rest, And are refreshed. In between, We live our lives, And are refreshed. We laugh, We cry, We love, We hate, We live, We die. And in the end, We are refreshed. So goes life.

My virtues are but vices grown respectable, And my best efforts are but poor pretenses. I am a bundle of contradictions, A creature of moods and fancies. I am neither good nor bad, Neither wise nor foolish, Neither happy nor unhappy. I am just me, A human being, Trying to make my way in the world. But I am not without hope. I know that I can change, That I can grow and learn. I am not perfect, But I am still worthy of love. I am a work in progress, A being in the making. I am not finished yet, But I am on my way.

Title: Poppies on the Wheat
First Line: Along Ancona’s hills the shimmering heat,
Whole Poem: Along Ancona’s hills the shimmering heat, A tropic tide of air with ebb and flow Bathes all the fields of wheat until they glow Like flashing seas of green, which toss and beat Around the vines. The poppies lithe and fleet Seem running, fiery torchmen, to and fro To mark the shore. The farmer does not know That they are there. He walks with heavy feet, Counting the bread and wine by autumn’s gain, But I,—I smile to think that days remain Perhaps to me in which, though bread be sweet No more, and red wine warm my blood in vain, I shall be glad remembering how the fleet, Lithe poppies ran like torchmen with the wheat.

The poppies nod and sway in the wind, Like crimson waves of blood; The wheat is reaped, the harvest's in, And autumn's call is heard. The poppies droop and fade away, Like crimson drops of rain; The wheat is gone, the winter's come, And spring's a-dreaming again. But still the poppies bloom and blow, A crimson gleam of light; A reminder of the summer's joy, And of the harvest's might.

The peasants in the fields are at their toil, And from the city comes the sound of bells, And from the sea the murmur of the waves. And in the midst of all this summer peace I sit and dream of days that are no more, Of days when I was young and life was sweet, And all the world was full of hope and joy. I dream of days when I was walking by The Arno’s side, and saw the sunset sky Reflected in its waters, and the stars Come out above the hills of Fiesole. I dream of days when I was wandering in The woods of Vallombrosa, and the sound Of the wind in the pines was like a voice That called me to come and rest. I dream of days when I was climbing the Hills of Fiesole, and saw the city below Spread out like a map, and all the world Was at my feet. And as I dream, the summer heat fades away, And the sound of the bells and the murmur of The waves are hushed, and I am back in those Days when life was young and life was sweet.

I love to watch the fishermen as they work, And to hear their songs as they haul in their nets. I love to see the children playing in the sand, And to hear their laughter as they run and play. I love to feel the warm sun on my skin, And to smell the fresh air of the sea. I am glad to be alive, And I am glad to be here in Ancona.

Title: Opportunity
First Line: I do not know if, climbing some steep hill,
Whole Poem: I do not know if, climbing some steep hill, Through fragrant wooded pass, this glimpse I bought, Or whether in some mid-day I was caught To upper air, where visions of God’s will In pictures to our quickened sense fulfil His word. But this I saw. A path I sought Through wall of rock. No human fingers wrought The golden gates which opened sudden, still, And wide. My fear was hushed by my delight. Surpassing fair the lands; my path lay plain; Alas, so spell-bound, feasting on the sight, I paused, that I but reached the threshold bright, When, swinging swift, the golden gates again Were rocky wall, by which I wept in vain.
Generation -- Title: Opportunity By Helen Hunt Jackson Of all the sad words of tongue or pen, The saddest are these: "It might have been!" Two roads diverged in a yellow wood, And sorry I could not travel both And be one traveler, long I stood And looked down one as far as I could To where it bent in the undergrowth; Then took the other, as just as fair, And having perhaps the better claim, Because it was grassy and wanted wear; Though as for that the passing there Had worn them really about the same, And both that morning equally lay In leaves no step had trodden black. Oh, I kept the first for another day! Yet knowing how way leads on to way, I doubted if I should ever come back. I shall be telling this with a sigh Somewhere ages and ages hence: Two roads diverged in a wood, and I— I took the one less traveled by, And that has made all the difference.

I see the light of hope shining above me, And I know that I shall reach it at last; So I will press on, And not give up, Until the goal is won. Title: Tides
First Line: O patient shore, that canst not go to meet
Whole Poem: O patient shore, that canst not go to meet Thy love, the restless sea, how comfortest Thou all thy loneliness? Art thou at rest, When, loosing his strong arms from round thy feet, He turns away? Know’st thou, however sweet That other shore may be, that to thy breast He must return? And when in sterner test He folds thee to a heart which does not beat, Wraps thee in ice, and gives no smile, no kiss, To break long wintry days, still dost thou miss Naught from thy trust? Still, wait, unfaltering, The higher, warmer waves which leap in spring? O sweet, wise shore, to be so satisfied! O heart, learn from the shore! Love has a tide!

The tide of joy is in my soul to-day, It fills my being with its golden light; The tide of sorrow is in my soul to-night, It fills my being with its gloom and night. But as the tides of the sea are ever changing, So the tides of joy and sorrow in my soul Are ever changing too; And as the sea is ever full, So my soul is ever full of joy and sorrow too. And as the tides of the sea are driven by the moon, So the tides of joy and sorrow in my soul Are driven by the unseen forces of the universe; And as the sea is ever restless, So my soul is ever restless too. But as the tides of the sea are always returning, So the tides of joy and sorrow in my soul Are always returning too; And as the sea is ever full, So my soul is ever full of joy and sorrow too.

Title: The Way to Sing
First Line: The birds must know. Who wisely sings Will sing as they;
Whole Poem: The birds must know. Who wisely sings Will sing as they; The common air has generous wings. Songs make their way. No messenger to run before, Devising plan; No mention of the place or hour To any man; No waiting till some sound betrays A listening ear; No different voice, no new delays, If steps draw near. What bird is that? Its song is good. And eager eyes Go peering through the dusky wood, In glad surprise. Then late at night, when by his fire The traveller sits, Watching the flame grow brighter, higher, The sweet song flits By snatches through his weary brain To help him rest; When next he goes that road again, An empty nest On leafless bough will make him sigh, Ah me! last spring Just here I heard, in passing by, That rare bird sing! But while he sighs, remembering How sweet the song, The little bird on tireless wing, Is borne along In other air, and other men With weary feet, On other roads, the simple strain Are finding sweet. The birds must know. Who wisely sings Will sing as they; The common air has generous wings, Songs make their way.

Singing is a song, And songs are fair. Sing with your heart, And your voice will soar. Sing with your soul, And your song will touch the stars. Sing with your mind, And your song will be wise. Sing with your body, And your song will be strong. Sing with all your being, And your song will be a thing of beauty.

He must be simple, like the lark, That sings at dawn; He must be joyful, like the thrush, That sings at noon; He must be grave, like the owl, That sings at night; He must be tender, like the dove, That sings in sorrow's spite. And he who would make his life a song Must learn to sing with all these birds, In simple joy and grave delight, In sorrow's spite, at dawn and noon and night.

Title: Excelsior
First Line: The shades of night were falling fast,
Whole Poem: The shades of night were falling fast, As through an Alpine village passed A youth, who bore, 'mid snow and ice, A banner with the strange device, Excelsior! His brow was sad; his eye beneath, Flashed like a falchion from its sheath, And like a silver clarion rung The accents of that unknown tongue, Excelsior! In happy homes he saw the light Of household fires gleam warm and bright; Above, the spectral glaciers shone, And from his lips escaped a groan, Excelsior! "Try not the Pass!" the old man said; "Dark lowers the tempest overhead, The roaring torrent is deep and wide!" And loud that clarion voice replied, Excelsior! "Oh stay," the maiden said, "and rest Thy weary head upon this breast! " A tear stood in his bright blue eye, But still he answered, with a sigh, Excelsior! "Beware the pine-tree's withered branch! Beware the awful avalanche!" This was the peasant's last Good-night, A voice replied, far up the height, Excelsior! At break of day, as heavenward The pious monks of Saint Bernard Uttered the oft-repeated prayer, A voice cried through the startled air, Excelsior! A traveller, by the faithful hound, Half-buried in the snow was found, Still grasping in his hand of ice That banner with the strange device, Excelsior! There in the twilight cold and gray, Lifeless, but beautiful, he lay, And from the sky, serene and far, A voice fell like a falling star, Excelsior!

His brow was sad, his eye was dim, But steadfast on his path he kept; And sternly spoke the mountain-wind, Excelsior! The village bells rang out a knell, And all the people wept and wailed; But he passed on with gleaming eye, Excelsior! Into the valley, dark and deep, Rising from the waves like a vapor, Went the youth, his dream above, Excelsior! At the eastern gate of heaven, Sat the angel with the flaming sword; In his hand he held a golden crown, And said, "Who enters here, must bear Excelsior!" Then the youth, with dauntless heart, Smote the angel's shield with his lance; And the gates of heaven were oped wide, And the youth passed through on his way, Excelsior!

His brow was sad, his cheek was pale, But his eye was bright and clear; And like a star, amid the gloom, That beacon burned so far and clear-- "Excelsior!" Onward he went, and passed the vale, The dripping rocks and snowy fells; The forests, dark at evening's close, Among whose sombre pines he hears The sound of waters, deep and hoarse-- "Excelsior!" O, ever on! his voice sublime Swells like the organ's pealing notes; The trumpet's blast, the battle's cry, The victor's shout, the dying groan, Are heard in that exulting cry-- "Excelsior!" But lo! the path is lost in snow; The summit is beyond his reach; And, weary with the toil, he sinks Upon the ground, and dies, but dies With joy, exclaiming with his latest breath-- "Excelsior!"

Title: Paul Revere’s Ride
First Line: Listen, my children, and you shall hear Of the midnight ride of Paul Revere,
Whole Poem: Listen, my children, and you shall hear Of the midnight ride of Paul Revere, On the eighteenth of April, in Seventy-Five: Hardly a man is now alive Who remembers that famous day and year. He said to his friend, “If the British march By land or sea from the town to-night, Hang a lantern aloft in the belfry-arch Of the North-Church-tower, as a signal-light,— One if by land, and two if by sea; And I on the opposite shore will be, Ready to ride and spread the alarm Through every Middlesex village and farm, For the country-folk to be up and to arm.” Then he said “Good night!” and with muffled oar Silently rowed to the Charlestown shore, Just as the moon rose over the bay, Where swinging wide at her moorings lay The Somerset, British man-of-war: A phantom ship, with each mast and spar Across the moon, like a prison-bar, And a huge black hulk, that was magnified By its own reflection in the tide. Meanwhile, his friend, through alley and street Wanders and watches with eager ears, Till in the silence around him he hears The muster of men at the barrack door, The sound of arms, and the tramp of feet, And the measured tread of the grenadiers Marching down to their boats on the shore. Then he climbed to the tower of the church, Up the wooden stairs, with stealthy tread, To the belfry-chamber overhead, And startled the pigeons from their perch On the sombre rafters, that round him made Masses and moving shapes of shade,— By the trembling ladder, steep and tall, To the highest window in the wall, Where he paused to listen and look down A moment on the roofs of the town, And the moonlight flowing over all. Beneath, in the churchyard, lay the dead, In their night-encampment on the hill, Wrapped in silence so deep and still That he could hear, like a sentinel’s tread, The watchful night-wind, as it went Creeping along from tent to tent, And seeming to whisper, “All is well!” A moment only he feels the spell Of the place and the hour, and the secret dread Of the lonely belfry and the dead; For suddenly all his thoughts are bent On a shadowy something far away, Where the river widens to meet the bay,— A line of black, that bends and floats On the rising tide, like a bridge of boats. Meanwhile, impatient to mount and ride, Booted and spurred, with a heavy stride, On the opposite shore walked Paul Revere. Now he patted his horse’s side, Now gazed on the landscape far and near, Then impetuous stamped the earth, And turned and tightened his saddle-girth; But mostly he watched with eager search The belfry-tower of the old North Church, As it rose above the graves on the hill, Lonely and spectral and sombre and still. And lo! as he looks, on the belfry’s height, A glimmer, and then a gleam of light! He springs to the saddle, the bridle he turns, But lingers and gazes, till full on his sight A second lamp in the belfry burns! A hurry of hoofs in a village-street, A shape in the moonlight, a bulk in the dark, And beneath from the pebbles, in passing, a spark Struck out by a steed that flies fearless and fleet: That was all! And yet, through the gloom and the light, The fate of a nation was riding that night; And the spark struck out by that steed, in his flight, Kindled the land into flame with its heat. He has left the village and mounted the steep, And beneath him, tranquil and broad and deep, Is the Mystic, meeting the ocean tides; And under the alders, that skirt its edge, Now soft on the sand, now loud on the ledge, Is heard the tramp of his steed as he rides. It was twelve by the village clock When he crossed the bridge into Medford town. He heard the crowing of the cock, And the barking of the farmer’s dog, And felt the damp of the river-fog, That rises when the sun goes down. It was one by the village clock, When he galloped into Lexington. He saw the gilded weathercock Swim in the moonlight as he passed, And the meeting-house windows, blank and bare, Gaze at him with a spectral glare, As if they already stood aghast At the bloody work they would look upon. It was two by the village clock, When he came to the bridge in Concord town. He heard the bleating of the flock, And the twitter of birds among the trees, And felt the breath of the morning breeze Blowing over the meadows brown. And one was safe and asleep in his bed Who at the bridge would be first to fall, Who that day would be lying dead, Pierced by a British musket-ball. You know the rest. In the books you have read, How the British Regulars fired and fled,— How the farmers gave them ball for ball, From behind each fence and farmyard-wall, Chasing the red-coats down the lane, Then crossing the fields to emerge again Under the trees at the turn of the road, And only pausing to fire and load. So through the night rode Paul Revere; And so through the night went his cry of alarm To every Middlesex village and farm,— A cry of defiance, and not of fear, A voice in the darkness, a knock at the door, And a word that shall echo forevermore! For, borne on the night-wind of the Past, Through all our history, to the last, In the hour of darkness and peril and need, The people will waken and listen to hear The hurrying hoof-beats of that steed, And the midnight message of Paul Revere.
Generation -- Firstline: Listen, my children, and you shall hear Of the midnight ride of Paul Revere, On the eighteenth of April, in Seventy-five; Hardly a man is now alive Who remembers that famous day and year. He said to his friend, "If the British march By land or sea from Boston town tonight, Hang a lantern aloft in the belfry arch Of the Old North Church tower as a signal light— One if by land, and two if by sea; And I on the opposite shore will be, Ready to ride and spread the alarm Through every Middlesex village and farm, For the country folk to be up and to arm." Then he said, "Good night! And have a pleasant ride!" And with a smile turned his horse's head, And away he went like a flash of light, Into the darkness of the night. And all along the shore, dimly seen, The flickering of lights from many a steeple, The village bells rang out in alarm, And the people came pouring out of their homes, By thousands and by tens of thousands, Armed with muskets and with pikes, Ready to fight for their homes and their rights, For their wives and their children, For the freedom of their native land. And so through the night rode Paul Revere; And so through the night went his cry of alarm To every Middlesex village and farm, A cry of defiance and of hope; A cry that echoed through the valleys and the hills, Through the forests and the fields, Echoed and re-echoed, Until the whole country heard the sound, And the people rose in arms to fight for their freedom. So the midnight ride of Paul Revere Became the signal for the American Revolution, And the battle cry, "One if by land, and two if by sea," Was heard throughout the land, And the people rose up to fight for their freedom.
Generation -- Firstline Only: On the eighteenth of April, in seventy-five; Hardly a man is now alive Who remembers that famous day and year. Now listen to me while I tell you again The story of the midnight ride of Paul Revere. It was just past midnight when Paul Revere Left his home in Boston town. He was riding to warn the American Minutemen that the British were coming. Revere rode through the darkness, Spurring his horse to a gallop. He rode through the sleeping towns, Calling out to the people, "The British are coming! The British are coming!" The people woke up in alarm, And they ran to their windows to see what was happening. They saw Paul Revere riding through the night, And they knew that the British were coming. Revere rode on and on, Never stopping until he reached Lexington. He met the American Minutemen there, And he told them that the British were coming. The Minutemen were ready for the British. They lined up on the village green, And they waited for the British to attack. The British came, And the Minutemen fought them bravely. The British were defeated, And they retreated back to Boston. The American Revolution had begun, And Paul Revere had played a key role in it. He had warned the Minutemen, And he had helped them to win the battle. Paul Revere was a hero, And his story is still told today. He is remembered as the man who rode Through the night to warn the Minutemen That the British were coming.

Title: A Psalm of Life
First Line: What The Heart Of The Young Man Said To The Psalmist. Tell me not, in mournful numbers,
Whole Poem: What The Heart Of The Young Man Said To The Psalmist. Tell me not, in mournful numbers, Life is but an empty dream! For the soul is dead that slumbers, And things are not what they seem. Life is real! Life is earnest! And the grave is not its goal; Dust thou art, to dust returnest, Was not spoken of the soul. Not enjoyment, and not sorrow, Is our destined end or way; But to act, that each to-morrow Find us farther than to-day. Art is long, and Time is fleeting, And our hearts, though stout and brave, Still, like muffled drums, are beating Funeral marches to the grave. In the world’s broad field of battle, In the bivouac of Life, Be not like dumb, driven cattle! Be a hero in the strife! Trust no Future, howe’er pleasant! Let the dead Past bury its dead! Act,— act in the living Present! Heart within, and God o’erhead! Lives of great men all remind us We can make our lives sublime, And, departing, leave behind us Footprints on the sands of time; Footprints, that perhaps another, Sailing o’er life’s solemn main, A forlorn and shipwrecked brother, Seeing, shall take heart again. Let us, then, be up and doing, With a heart for any fate; Still achieving, still pursuing, Learn to labor and to wait.

Let us, then, be up and doing, With a heart for any fate; Still achieving, still pursuing, Learn to labor and to wait. * * * Life is real! Life is earnest! And the grave is not its goal; Dust thou art, to dust returnest, Was not spoken of the soul. * * * Not enjoyment, and not sorrow, Is our destined end or way; But to act, that each tomorrow Find us farther than today. * * * Leverage your time, and energies, To improve the present hour; Not in slothful ease, but in strenuous deeds, Let us mold our future's character. * * * Lives of great men all remind us We can make our lives sublime, And, departing, leave behind us Footprints on the sands of time; Footprints, that perhaps another, Sailing o'er life's solemn main, A forlorn and shipwrecked brother, Seeing, shall take heart again.

Title: The Wreck of the Hesperus
First Line: It was the schooner Hesperus, That sailed the wintry sea;
Whole Poem: It was the schooner Hesperus, That sailed the wintry sea; And the skipper had taken his little daughtèr, To bear him company. Blue were her eyes as the fairy-flax, Her cheeks like the dawn of day, And her bosom white as the hawthorn buds, That ope in the month of May. The skipper he stood beside the helm, His pipe was in his mouth, And he watched how the veering flaw did blow The smoke now West, now South. Then up and spake an old Sailòr, Had sailed to the Spanish Main, "I pray thee, put into yonder port, For I fear a hurricane. "Last night, the moon had a golden ring, And to-night no moon we see!" The skipper, he blew a whiff from his pipe, And a scornful laugh laughed he. Colder and louder blew the wind, A gale from the Northeast, The snow fell hissing in the brine, And the billows frothed like yeast. Down came the storm, and smote amain The vessel in its strength; She shuddered and paused, like a frighted steed, Then leaped her cable's length. "Come hither! come hither! my little daughtèr, And do not tremble so; For I can weather the roughest gale That ever wind did blow." He wrapped her warm in his seaman's coat Against the stinging blast; He cut a rope from a broken spar, And bound her to the mast. "O father! I hear the church-bells ring, Oh say, what may it be?" "'T is a fog-bell on a rock-bound coast!" — And he steered for the open sea. "O father! I hear the sound of guns, Oh say, what may it be?" "Some ship in distress, that cannot live In such an angry sea!" "O father! I see a gleaming light, Oh say, what may it be?" But the father answered never a word, A frozen corpse was he. Lashed to the helm, all stiff and stark, With his face turned to the skies, The lantern gleamed through the gleaming snow On his fixed and glassy eyes. Then the maiden clasped her hands and prayed That savèd she might be; And she thought of Christ, who stilled the wave On the Lake of Galilee. And fast through the midnight dark and drear, Through the whistling sleet and snow, Like a sheeted ghost, the vessel swept Tow'rds the reef of Norman's Woe. And ever the fitful gusts between A sound came from the land; It was the sound of the trampling surf On the rocks and the hard sea-sand. The breakers were right beneath her bows, She drifted a dreary wreck, And a whooping billow swept the crew Like icicles from her deck. She struck where the white and fleecy waves Looked soft as carded wool, But the cruel rocks, they gored her side Like the horns of an angry bull. Her rattling shrouds, all sheathed in ice, With the masts went by the board; Like a vessel of glass, she stove and sank, Ho! ho! the breakers roared! At daybreak, on the bleak sea-beach, A fisherman stood aghast, To see the form of a maiden fair, Lashed close to a drifting mast. The salt sea was frozen on her breast, The salt tears in her eyes; And he saw her hair, like the brown sea-weed, On the billows fall and rise. Such was the wreck of the Hesperus, In the midnight and the snow! Christ save us all from a death like this, On the reef of Norman's Woe!
Generation -- Title: It was the schooner Hesperus, That sailed the wintry sea; And the skipper had taken his little daughter, To bear him company. He had taken her up from the sea-beach, Where the waves were dancing free; And he said, "My little daughter, Do not fear the stormy sea; For I am a good sailor, And I've weathered many a gale; And I'll bring you safe to land, My little daughter, before the gale." So they sailed away, Over the wintry sea; And the little girl watched the snow-flakes, As they fell into the sea. And she said, "Father, I am cold; And the wind is whistling shrill; And I am afraid, father, Of the storm that is so wild." But the father said, "My little daughter, Do not fear the storm; For I am a good sailor, And I've weathered many a gale; And I'll bring you safe to land, My little daughter, before the gale." And they sailed on, Over the stormy sea; And the little girl watched the waves, As they rose and fell. And she said, "Father, I am tired; And I want to go to sleep; And I am afraid, father, Of the storm that is so loud." But the father said, "My little daughter, Do not fear the storm; For I am a good sailor, And I've weathered many a gale; And I'll bring you safe to land, My little daughter, before the gale." So the little girl went to sleep, And the father watched over her; And the storm raged on, But the Hesperus sailed on. But at midnight, came a terrible cry, And the Hesperus went down; And the father was lost, And the little daughter was lost; And the only thing that was saved, Was the little daughter's cloak. And it was washed up on the beach, Where the little girl had played; And the people said, "This is the cloak Of the little daughter of the Hesperus." And they wrapped it around the little girl, Who was cold and wet; And she smiled, and said, "Father is here; And he has brought me safe to land." And the people were very kind to her, And they took her to their homes; And she lived among them, And she was happy.
