Title: The American Soldier
First Line: A Picture from the Life To serve with love, And shed your blood, Approved may be above, But here below (Example shew,) ‘Tis dangerous to be good. --Lord Oxford Deep in a vale, a stranger now to arms,
Whole Poem: A Picture from the Life To serve with love, And shed your blood, Approved may be above, But here below (Example shew,) ‘Tis dangerous to be good. --Lord Oxford Deep in a vale, a stranger now to arms, Too poor to shine in courts, too proud to beg, He, who once warred on Saratoga’s plains, Sits musing o’er his scars, and wooden leg. Remembering still the toil of former days, To other hands he sees his earnings paid;-- They share the due reward—he feeds on praise. Lost in the abyss of want, misfortune’s shade. Far, far from domes where splendid tapers glare, ‘Tis his from dear bought peace no wealth to win, Removed alike from courtly cringing ‘squires, The great-man’s Levee, and the proud man’s grin. Sold are those arms which once on Britons blazed, When, flushed with conquest, to the charge they came; That power repelled, and Freedom’s fabrick raised, She leaves her soldier—famine and a name!
Generation -- Title: The American Soldier By Philip Freneau In the days of yore, when Freedom's flame First kindled in the breasts of men, A band of heroes sprung to fame, Who fought for right and battled for the free. They fought for liberty and truth, For justice and for equal laws; They fought for homes and loved ones, too, And for the rights of all the human race. They fought and bled, and many died, But they won the victory for us all; And now we stand, a free and happy land, Thanks to the brave American soldier. The American soldier is a man of courage, A man of honor, and a man of truth; He is a defender of the weak, A protector of the innocent, And a champion of freedom. The American soldier is a symbol of our nation, A symbol of our strength, And a symbol of our hope. We are proud of our American soldiers, And we are grateful for their service. They are the guardians of our freedom, And they are the protectors of our way of life. We salute the American soldier, And we thank them for all that they do.
Generation -- Firstline: A Picture from the Life To serve with love, And shed your blood, Approved may be above, But here below (Example shew,) ‘Tis dangerous to be good. --Lord Oxford Deep in a vale, a stranger now to arms, I hear the trump and drum; The battle’s roar comes distant on the gale, And bids my spirit come. I leave my peaceful home, And haste to join the war; For I have heard the tyrant’s voice, And I must arm for the poor. I fight for those who cannot fight for themselves, And for the rights of man; I fight for those who groan beneath the rod, And for the land of the free. I fight for justice, For liberty, and for law; I fight for those who love their country well, And for those who love it not at all. I fight for the right, And for the true, And for the good; And I will fight till every tyrant is subdued. I fight for the future, For the children yet to be born; I fight for a world where all men are free, And where all men are born equal. I fight for a world where peace reigns supreme, And where love is the law; I fight for a world where all men are brothers, And where all men are one. I fight for a world where every man can live in peace, And where every man can be himself; I fight for a world where every man can be free, And where every man can be happy. I fight for a world where all men are equal, And where all men are free; I fight for a world where all men are brothers, And where all men are one.
Generation -- Firstline Only: The warrior rests, his weary course is run; No more he hears the trumpet’s thrilling sound, No more he meets the foeman’s levelled lance. The sword he loved so well now rusts beside him, And his bright shield is hung upon the wall; His war-horse grazes in the quiet meadow, And his plumed helmet moulders in the dust. He thinks upon the days of old, when he led his gallant band to victory; He remembers the bloody fields he fought upon, And the comrades who fell by his side. But he is glad to rest, and he knows that he has fought a good fight; He has served his country faithfully, and he has won the love and respect of his fellow-men. He is content to live in peace and quietness, and to enjoy the fruits of his labours; He knows that he has done his duty, and he leaves the rest to God. He is a picture from the life, a man who has lived and fought and won; He is a reminder that there are still good men in the world, men who are willing to serve their country and their fellow-men.

Title: The Indian Burying Ground
First Line: In spite of all the learned have said, I still my old opinion keep;
Whole Poem: In spite of all the learned have said, I still my old opinion keep; The posture, that we give the dead, Points out the soul's eternal sleep. Not so the ancients of these lands— The Indian, when from life released, Again is seated with his friends, And shares again the joyous feast. His imaged birds, and painted bowl, And venison, for a journey dressed, Bespeak the nature of the soul, Activity, that knows no rest. His bow, for action ready bent, And arrows, with a head of stone, Can only mean that life is spent, And not the old ideas gone. Thou, stranger, that shalt come this way, No fraud upon the dead commit— Observe the swelling turf, and say They do not lie, but here they sit. Here still a lofty rock remains, On which the curious eye may trace (Now wasted, half, by wearing rains) The fancies of a ruder race. Here still an aged elm aspires, Beneath whose far-projecting shade (And which the shepherd still admires) The children of the forest played! There oft a restless Indian queen (Pale Shebah, with her braided hair) And many a barbarous form is seen To chide the man that lingers there. By midnight moons, o'er moistening dews; In habit for the chase arrayed, The hunter still the deer pursues, The hunter and the deer, a shade! And long shall timorous fancy see The painted chief, and pointed spear, And Reason's self shall bow the knee To shadows and delusions here.
Generation -- Firstline: In spite of all the learned have said, I still my old opinion keep; That Nature's God is good to all, And does his creatures never sleep. He gives the fowls of air their food, And corn and wine to make us glad; He sends the sun to warm the earth, And bids the rain in showers descend. He makes the trees to grow and bear, And gives the fruit to all who share; He spreads the earth with flowers and grass, And decks the meadows with the dew. He fills the sea with fish and shell, And makes the rivers run with health; He gives the winds their wings to fly, And bids the waves in billows roll. He made the world for all mankind, And gave to every creature kind A right to share the gifts he gave, And live in peace and joy and love. Then let us love our fellow-men, And do to others as we would be done unto; And let us praise the Lord for all his gifts, And live in peace and joy and love.
Generation -- Firstline Only: I hold it right to be merry and glad, And to do good while I live.

Title: The Englishman's Complaint
First Line: Arriving from Britain with cargo so nice Once more have I touched at these regions of rice!
Whole Poem: Arriving from Britain with cargo so nice Once more have I touched at these regions of rice! Dear Ashley, with pleasure thy stream I review: But how changed are these plains that we wished to subdue. If through the wild woods he extended his reign, And death and the hangman were both in his train, Cornwallis no longer disturbs your repose, His lordship is dead or at least in a doze. By Sullivan's island how quiet we pass; Fort Johnson no longer salutes us, alas!— The season has been you did nothing but mourn, But now you will laugh at a Briton's return! Instead of gay soldiers that walked the parade, Here is nothing but draymen and people in trade; Instead of our navy that thundered around, Here is nothing but ships without guns to be found. Instead of Lord Rawdon and Nesbit Balfour, Whose names and whose notions you cannot endure, But whom in their glory you could not forget When puffed by the froth of the Royal Gazette: Instead of those tyrants, who homewards have flown, This country is ruled by a race of its own, Whom once we could laugh at—but now we must say Seem rising to be in a handsomer way. To us and our island eternally foes, How tedious you are in forgetting your woes, Your plundered plantations you still will remember, Although we have left you—three years last December!

Title: The Wild Honeysuckle
First Line: Fair flower, that dost so comely grow,
Whole Poem: Fair flower, that dost so comely grow, Hid in this silent, dull retreat, Untouch’d thy honey’d blossoms blow, Unseen thy little branches greet: No roving foot shall crush thee here, No busy hand provoke a tear. By Nature’s self in white array’d, She bade thee shun the vulgar eye, And planted here the guardian shade, And sent soft waters murmuring by; Thus quietly thy summer goes, Thy days declining to repose. Smit with those charms, that must decay, I grieve to see thy future doom; They died—nor were those flowers more gay, (The flowers that did in Eden bloom) Unpitying frosts and Autumn’s power Shall leave no vestige of this flower. From morning suns and evening dews At first thy little being came: If nothing once, you nothing lose, For when you die you are the same; The space between is but an hour, The mere idea of a flower.
Generation -- Title: **The Wild Honeysuckle** From youth to age I love thee still, My gentle wildwood flower; When summer suns grow fierce and bright, And winter's storms are near. In every season thou art fair, And lovely to behold; And oft I've breathed thy balmy air, When sick and faint and old. Thy fragrance fills the summer air, And sweetens every breeze; And oft I've listened to thy song, When all beside was still. I love to hear thee at the dawn, When first thy voice is heard; It seems to wake the sleeping earth, And bid the world rejoice. I love to hear thee at the close Of day, when all is still; Thy gentle voice is like a prayer, That soothes my weary soul. The wild honeysuckle is a flower That brings to mind my childhood days; And when I see it in the woods, It fills my heart with joy. I love thee, gentle wildwood flower, And thou shalt ever be A part of my life, And of my memory.
Generation -- Firstline: Fair flower, that dost so comely grow, Hiding thy sweets beneath the snow, Whence comest thou, and whither goest? Tell me, thou gentle flower, I pray. I come from fields of light and air, Where summer suns for ever are; I come to cheer the wintry hours, And breathe of life on frozen flowers. I love the cold, and I love the snow, And all the storms that winter brings; For in my native fields they blow The sweetest music to my wings. I love to see the children play In the bright snow on Christmas day; And I love to hear their merry shout, As they dance around the Christmas tree. I love to see the old folks sit By the fireside and talk of days gone by; And I love to hear their stories told, Of the good old times when I was a child. So I come to you, dear children, To bring you joy and happiness; To make you forget your winter cares, And to fill your hearts with love and peace. I am a flower of the winter, And I bring you the greetings of the spring; I am a messenger of hope, And I bring you the promise of a brighter day.

Title: Georgia Dusk
First Line: The sky, lazily disdaining to pursue The setting sun, too indolent to hold
Whole Poem: The sky, lazily disdaining to pursue The setting sun, too indolent to hold A lengthened tournament for flashing gold, Passively darkens for night’s barbecue, A feast of moon and men and barking hounds, An orgy for some genius of the South With blood-hot eyes and cane-lipped scented mouth, Surprised in making folk-songs from soul sounds. The sawmill blows its whistle, buzz-saws stop, And silence breaks the bud of knoll and hill, Soft settling pollen where plowed lands fulfill Their early promise of a bumper crop. Smoke from the pyramidal sawdust pile Curls up, blue ghosts of trees, tarrying low Where only chips and stumps are left to show The solid proof of former domicile. Meanwhile, the men, with vestiges of pomp, Race memories of king and caravan, High-priests, an ostrich, and a juju-man, Go singing through the footpaths of the swamp. Their voices rise . . the pine trees are guitars, Strumming, pine-needles fall like sheets of rain . . Their voices rise . . the chorus of the cane Is caroling a vesper to the stars . . O singers, resinous and soft your songs Above the sacred whisper of the pines, Give virgin lips to cornfield concubines, Bring dreams of Christ to dusky cane-lipped throngs.
Generation -- Firstline: The sky, lazily disdaining to pursue The setting sun, too indolent to hold, Sinks down behind the western wave; the lake A fiery opal, burns with liquid gold. The clouds, like galleons, sailing in the west, Float in the crimson light; and in the east The mountains, like a purple dream, are seen. The fire of sunset fades; the lake grows dim; The clouds are scattered; and the mountains seem To sleep, like weary children, in the night. The stars come out; the moon shines in the sky; And all is still, save for the sound of waves That break upon the shore.
Generation -- Firstline Only: The glory of the day, resignedly lets All that bright pageant fade, and calmly yields Its place to sombre night.

Title: Song of the Son
First Line: Pour O pour that parting soul in song,
Whole Poem: Pour O pour that parting soul in song, O pour it in the sawdust glow of night, Into the velvet pine-smoke air tonight, And let the valley carry it along. And let the valley carry it along. O land and soil, red soil and sweet-gum tree, So scant of grass, so profligate of pines, Now just before an epoch’s sun declines Thy son, in time, I have returned to thee. Thy son, I have in time returned to thee. In time, for though the sun is setting on A song-lit race of slaves, it has not set; Though late, O soil, it is not too late yet To catch thy plaintive soul, leaving, soon gone, Leaving, to catch thy plaintive soul soon gone. O Negro slaves, dark purple ripened plums, Squeezed, and bursting in the pine-wood air, Passing, before they stripped the old tree bare One plum was saved for me, one seed becomes An everlasting song, a singing tree, Caroling softly souls of slavery, What they were, and what they are to me, Caroling softly souls of slavery.
Generation -- Title: **Song of the Son** I heard my father's voice in the wind today Blowing through the mesquite trees Like a trumpet calling me to come away. I heard my father's voice in the wind today Saying, "Son, come home. Leave the fields and the cotton. Leave the sun and the hoe. Come home, son, And talk to me." I heard my father's voice in the wind today Saying, "Son, I'm tired. I'm tired of working in the fields. I'm tired of the sun and the hoe. Come home, son, And rest with me." I heard my father's voice in the wind today Saying, "Son, I'm lonely. I'm lonely for your laughter. I'm lonely for your voice. Come home, son, And be with me." I heard my father's voice in the wind today And I knew that I had to go home. I had to go home to my father. I left the fields and the cotton. I left the sun and the hoe. I went home to my father. I went home and talked to my father. I told him how I was doing. I told him about my life. My father listened to me. He smiled at me. He hugged me. My father was happy to see me. I was happy to be home. We sat together in the shade of the mesquite trees. We talked and we laughed. We were together. And I was content.
Generation -- Firstline: Pour O pour that parting soul in song O pour it in the vessel of the earth. Let us chant together a measure of its worth: Earth, receive an honored guest; Earth, lift your chalice to the brim and pour To one whose passion matched your own, Whose lips were touched with fire, whose heart with flame. Pour O pour that parting soul in song. He was the poet of the people, The voice of the disinherited, The prophet of a new day. He sang of the beauty of the earth, Of the joy of life, of the hope of freedom. He was a man of vision, A man of courage, A man of love. He died at the dawn of a new day, But his spirit will live on forever. Pour O pour that parting soul in song. Let us sing of his life, Of his work, Of his dreams. Let us sing of the joy he brought to the world, Of the hope he gave to the oppressed, Of the love he shared with all. Pour O pour that parting soul in song. Let us sing him into the future, A bright future of peace and justice, A future of freedom and equality, A future of love and brotherhood. Pour O pour that parting soul in song.
Generation -- Firstline Only: O pour it in the ocean wide, That it may onward bear the breath, Of the dead, across the tide.

Title: Portrait in Georgia
First Line: Hair–braided chestnut,
Whole Poem: Hair–braided chestnut, coiled like a lyncher’s rope, Eye–fagots, Lips–old scars, or the first red blisters, Breath–the last sweet scent of cane, And her slim body, white as the ash of black flesh after flame.

Hair–braided chestnut, Woven in and out of dreams, Dreams of the soft, brown earth, Dreams of the strong, black sea. Hair–braided chestnut, Woven in and out of life, Life of the warm, brown body, Life of the laughing soul.
